It's no secret that Batman has quite a few movies under his utility belt, but there's one core aspect of his character that's rarely been shown on the big screen: his detective skills. He is known as the "World's Greatest Detective" after all, yet in most of his films, we don't see him do much investigating… until now. More so than a traditional comic book movie, ‘The Batman', from director/producer/co-writer Matt Reeves, is a detective story, a refreshing change of pace from the character's previous live-action installments. In the film, Gotham City's elite and "upstanding" citizens become the targets of a mysterious serial killer called the Riddler, and Batman (two years into his crime-fighting crusade), along with GCPD Lieutenant Jim Gordon, must solve his clues in order to put an end to the bloodshed, all the while uncovering corruption and lies kept hidden by the city's rich and powerful. Along the way, they encounter an intriguing cast of characters, including unlikely ally Selina Kyle, crime boss Carmine Falcone, and Oswald "Oz" Cobblepot aka the Penguin, Falcone's lieutenant and proprietor of the Iceberg Lounge nightclub. Every single member of the cast is incredible, with many of them becoming my personal favorite live-action adaptations of their respective character, such as Robert Pattinson's titular Dark Knight, who exudes a quiet intensity and is able to convey a multitude of emotions without speaking a word, and Colin Farrell's Penguin, who is utterly unrecognizable in the role and steals every scene he's in, to name a few. The film itself is captivating and incredibly well-paced despite having a nearly 3-hour runtime, and my eyes were glued to the screen throughout the entirety of it. One reason for this is the fact that ‘The Batman' is easily the most beautifully-shot comic book movie I've ever seen, due to the exceptionally brilliant work of cinematographer Greig Fraser. I also have to give major praise to composer Michael Giacchino and production designer James Chinlund, whose music and sets elevated the film to a whole new level and filled me with excitement, suspense, and many more emotions. Overall, Matt Reeves and co. have proven that they truly understand the characters they're working with and have crafted a smart, gripping masterpiece set in a new Bat-universe which I'm incredibly eager to revisit as soon as possible and will hopefully continue for many years to come.

This detective just happened to dress in an intimidating bat costume (which was also more gritty and realistic), and had excellent, believable fighting skills. There were some great twists and surprises that made this story even more entertaining.

The sets, lighting, and music worked together seamlessly to pull me in to the world where Gotham City was real and corruption thrived. There were no campy costumes and Catwoman didn't purr like a cartoon villain. The criminals didn't have gimmicky lairs and even the Batcave came across as rugged and realistic. If I didn't know any better I would have thought someone dropped New York City in a dark Washington State during the rainy season.

Overall I would name this the best Batman ever in both movies and television. The actors were believable, sympathetic, and I actually cared what happened to them. I'll admit when I heard Robert Pattinson was going to be the new Batman, I scoffed at the idea; but he proved me wrong. He turned out to be one of the best. I hope this franchise continues through many more films.

On first viewing, in the theater, I thought The Batman to be loud, long, and somewhat slow-paced. I found the slow motion scenes to be overly used and detracting from the story. I didn't love Andy Serkis as Alfred. Pattinson, though he had impressed me in his post-glampire appearances, was far from my first choices to don the cape. And DC has dropped one steaming turd after another in the past decade and a half as if a team of caffeinated tweens were running the entire WBfilm studios. 

But ultimately I dismissed these as minor gripes, ate my popcorn, and somewhat enjoyed a sunday movie which I intended on quickly forgetting. 

But I didn't forget it. I thought about...a lot. It bugged me that I liked it more than I wanted to, and I wanted to hate it. I got on YouTube to seek out scathing video reviews to help me feel better about wanting to hate it, there's PLENTY on there.  Which is when I happened on a YouTube video posted by the channel: Macabre Storytelling called "Why The Batman is NOT a Batman Film". ( https://youtu.be/tyRnkwo4Pds ) and it completely changed my mind. It gave such a fresh perspective that, in my haste to hate, had originally gone well over my head. After viewing the movie a second time, this time through the lens of perspective given by the video, I see The Batman as arguably the best Batman Film to date. 

That slow pacing and those slo-mo shots no longer irked me. They drew me in to the emotional weight of the story, allowing me to soak in the surrounding atmosphere. Permitting me to experience a quiet moment in an otherwise chaotic City. Seeing Batman where he is between the angry kid from origin tales and the polished veteran crimefighter of later years...seeing him as a still confused young man in his coming of age tale, processing the results of his actions and seeing that he is a small part of the bigger picture...really resonated in a way that no other batman Film has done before. He had the power, but hadn't yet figured out the responsibility. He isn't Batman yet, he is just raw, and mostly blind, if not at least tone deaf "vengeance". 

Paul Dano's Riddler was chilling, haunting, and such a refreshing take on a character that has been too often cast as comic relief. Pattinson shined in a role where the one-dimensionality of the character is intentional. The real test will be in the (hopeful) sequel where he'll have the chance to spread his acting wings and we'll see his diversity as Batwayne. Zoe is a very strong actress, she shines here. And she's stunning in a role where she is comically undersized for. Her fight scenes, though well shot and very exciting, were a hard pill to swallow given her diminutive stature. But I was no less entertained. 
 
It has subtly brilliant storytelling with some gorgeously choreographed violence, that often gets overlooked to the casual or average comic book movie fan. These "fans" watch for the action and the side humor (which has taken a far too comfortable front seat over in the MCU these days), and shun anything that could be mistaken for intelligence. With its attention to detail and depth of character rivaling Fincher himself, it's more a film, than a movie. And that, to some, is too high of a concept to comprehend. I can't help but give The Batman damn close to five stars. A not quite profound, but deeply appreciated pleasure to experience.

I have always been obsessed with Batman from an early age as I have watched the animated series, the Justice League series, Lego Batman and other Batman media content. As I grew up, I stopped watching Batman related media for a while until this movie released. Directed by Matt Reeves, The Batman 2022 is a reboot from the previous Batman films and this time, this movie depicts a more realistic Gotham city with a dark, noir and  detective style story of Batman who takes on the job of protecting Gotham city and when I mean by realistic, there are no superpowers and superhuman beings at all. Realistic scenarios, realistic hand to hand combat scenes, vehicles and the list could go on. This movie is very different from your usual action packed superhero films like the movies  Marvel would usually make. So, I suggest you turn back if you are one of those superhero movie fans that cares about action scenes and superpowers because you are going to witness something different.
    The film itself is aesthetically pleasing and I mean it for the entire movie which I will explain more about later in this review.
   The story takes place 2 years after The Batman publicized himself to Gotham city, a city with filled with corruption and crime. While keeping a lookout for the city, a serial killer named Riddler emerges and starts killing influential figures of Gotham city, whom all have  corrupt connections to each other and also leaving clues that leads up to an even greater conspiracy. Batman must solve all these mysteries and riddles in order to find out who the next target is, solve the conspiracy and put an end to the Riddler. Does he have what it takes to stop the Riddler?
Robert Pattinson nails the role as Batman: a depressed and edgy caped crusader (this is what most people like to call him) who is scarred by the death of his parents 20 years ago caused by a group of criminals. He was able to capture the vibe of a dark and depressed person that Batman is: Does not talk much, blunt and an intimidating vigilante that the Batman is known for. He also played the other side of Batman as well, Bruce Wayne. When Bruce is not under his mask and suit, he is just a depressed billionaire who owns the Wayne enterprise and deals with public affairs and still as edgy as Batman. Robert Pattison was able to portray both Bruce Wayne and Batman very well. You can just look into his eyes and feel that dark and gloomy vibe.
 Supporting roles like the Cat woman (Zoey was spot on with the sassy attitude) and commissioner police Gordon were also done very well as they were able to show how it is like to partner up with Batman, who is stubborn, quiet and straightforward. Paul Dano as the Riddler was immaculate as he managed to play as a menacing and mentally deranged person who is just a normal human being that can cause disruption and violence in Gotham city. He showed off his performance even furthermore in the scene where he talks with Batman in Arkham Asylum.  Colin Farrell also brought the character Penguin to life with the accent and the personality which was spot on like the comics. The same exact thing could be said for the actor who played the crime boss Carmine Falcone. All the actors managed to bring the characters to life just by the way they talked in the movie. You could even feel the tension during the characters' conversations.

  Cinematography in this movie is top tier. Some will think the camera work is too much, but I think that doing too much is what made the film beautiful. The still shots of Gotham city from different perspectives, still shots of the characters, the shots of Batman looking over Gotham city, the dark color palate used and especially the lighting the movies uses, it makes the film look and feel dark. The fight scenes' fast paced camera work was executed properly as it perfectly choreographed all the fighting moves and the camera follows the Batman while he performs all these fighting techniques making us feel the intense action.
The scene where Batman revs up his Bat mobile in the dark and reveals himself was one of the best cameras work, I have seen in my life. The way the engine lights up showing the flames, the full view of the Batmobile from all perspective, the terrifying engine sounds the Batmobile makes, it's just top tier. That moment was pure hype fuel.  I could feel that intimidating appearance of the Batmobile. The movie felt immersive due to its excellent camera work and cinematography.
   The music and soundtrack used was a perfect fit for the impressive cinematography as the music enhanced every moment in the movie. Every fight scene and chase scenes felt intense due to the fitting soundtrack. You could even feel the tension between the characters conversations.
 However, the length of the movie felt unnecessary in my opinion. Sure, all the scenes were pretty, but some scenes could be cut out as it felt like it, they were not necessary for the movie's plot. With that time, they could have explored more areas of Gotham city or show more characters. Other than that, the movie is superb.
   Overall, this Batman movie is a dark, gritty and realistic take on Batman and Gotham city with a fascinating psychological thriller story that will keep you asking many questions while watching the film. This film will not be for those who enjoy action packed superhero films as this movie have dark and depressing themes and the long length of the film might scare some people away. But try it out, see if you like it or not. I would recommend this movie to every Batman fans though. 4/5 stars movie and very excited for a sequel.

‘Planet of the Apes' writer/director Matt Reeves directs Robert Pattinson in this stylish reboot of the caped crusader. Pattinson leads an A-list cast that includes Zoë Kravitz, Jeffrey Wright, Colin Farrell, Paul Dano and Andy Serkis. Reeves delivers a masterclass in filmmaking, bringing a dark, gritty adaptation of Batman to the screen that leaves you wanting more as soon as the credits roll.

When The Riddler (Paul Dano) begins his killing spree, targeting Gotham City's key political figures, billionaire Bruce Wayne is called into action donning the iconic cowl as he begins to investigate. As Bruce explores the deep-rooted corruption hidden behind some of Gotham's most well-known figures, the full scale of the sadistic serial killer's plan comes to light, forcing Bruce to question his past as he tries to save the city of Gotham and its people.

‘Dune' cinematographer Greig Fraser adds to his stellar streak of work, providing ‘The Batman' with sensational cinematography, creating a gothic feast for the eyes while also capturing the dark underbelly of Gotham City. Fraser's visuals allow for this film to be not only a visual spectacle, but also a thoroughly entertaining film. Much like James Mangold's ‘Logan' or Christopher Nolan's Dark Knight Trilogy, ‘The Batman' positions itself as one of the darker superhero adaptations – both thematically and narratively, as well as visually. Acclaimed composer Michael Giacchino crafts a magnificent score for the film, creating an addictive mix of booming orchestral pieces and eerie choir pieces. Giacchino's new theme for the caped crusader, an intense and thundering piece of music will arguably go on to define the character for years to come.

Despite the hefty near three-hour run-time, Matt Reeves ensures that audiences are kept on the edges of their seats and entertained throughout. Robert Pattinson slips effortlessly into the role as the iconic hero, giving a marvellous performance as an intimidating hero, and mysterious billionaire. Pattinson's performance leaves you eagerly anticipating for when the ‘Twilight' star next dons the emblematic cowl, with a portrayal that manages to capture Batman's humanity so easily and subtlety.

Paul Dano arguably gives the best performance of the film; crafting himself into a terrifying villain, lighting up every second of screen-time he gets. Dano and Pattinson's performances are accompanied by a slick turn as Selina Kyle/Catwoman from ‘Big Little Lies' star Zoë Kravitz, who gives a brilliant performance as the feline anti-hero. However, Colin Farrell's unrecognisable turn ‘The Penguin' can't help but feel like an unnecessary addition to the plot, coming off as a character who's only reason for being included was to set up the character's own HBO Max miniseries currently in the works.

Despite being one of the best films of 2022 so far, ‘The Batman' can't help but suffer from a few issues, including a disjointed third act that ultimately wins you over with a nail-biting final sequence and certain . Matt Reeves threads together a wide web of themes in ‘The Batman' ranging from justice, corruption, to crime and greed. These complex themes come together to create a cryptic, intricate, and multi-layered story that keeps you on your toes, constantly guessing these character's next moves. ‘Planet of the Apes' production designer James Chinlund and ‘Spencer' costume designer Jacqueline Durran bring their respective talents together to create an immersive world that draws you into the crime-ridden streets of Gotham.

Matt Reeves puts his spin on the iconic hero with Warner Bros. latest edition to their plethora of DC films. Driven by a cast that give marvellous performances throughout the three-hour run-time, ‘The Batman' presents a much darker and mysterious version of the well-loved hero to audiences, inviting them to try and solve The Riddler's mystery alongside Bruce Wayne. The film does a stellar job of not only establishing new versions of these characters, but also sets up the future of Robert Pattinson's turn as Batman. Teasing new villains and exciting returns, ‘The Batman' is sure to be a film that audiences will absolutely enjoy, whether you're a DC fan or not.

The Batman does more right than wrong, but it's a touch overindulgent at very nearly 3 hours. This film, as anticipated, serves as a sort of showcase for an upcoming series of films, introducing several noteworthy names throughout the first chunk of the film. Catwoman, Penguin, The Riddler, and that's to say nothing of the less flashy but just as crucial Alfred Pennyworth or the Police Lieutenant, not-yet-Commissioner Jim Gordon. More characters work than do not, but it would have been nice to see a little development, especially for Paul Dano's transfixing take on The Riddler. Completely unhinged, but also calculating Dano's work as the deeply disturbed Edward deserved more screen time without his strange and haunting mask. This Riddler is nothing like the ones you've seen before, and Dano's take is certainly the best Batman villain since Heath Ledger's infamous offering. By the film's conclusion they do give him a backstory, but it's done in a real "fly by" sort of way. The backstory itself is nice and cookie-cuter neat so that it fits in the small window of time allotted for it. Ultimately it doesn't do the film's best character justice, but the performance is still commendable regardless. As for the rest of the cast, they do a fine job - no major complaints, but the film certainly does it's utmost to keep Batman onscreen by keeping Bruce Wayne off of it. While Pattinson does fine behind the cowl, his Bruce Wayne leaves something to be desired. Perhaps the most complete character in the film is Gotham itself. Here the backdrops are all dirty and unkempt, strewn with litter and soot. It rains more often than not here, casting the entirety of the city in a looming hopelessness that's almost palpable. It serves as a constant reminder of the mindset of the people who live there, surrounded by crime and wealthy exuberance, unsafe and too poor to combat the obvious corruption within Gotham's inner workings. This is perhaps best exemplified by John Turturro's transfixing take on Carmine Falcone, a well-known mob boss in Gotham city. Turturro, like Dano, doesn't get the screen time he deserves, but manages to do a lot with the limited time that he is allowed. The story represents a more detective-based approach that was often lacking a certain authenticity in Nolan's trilogy, which is quite welcome overall and it fills the lengthy runtime fairly well as The Riddler leads Batman all over Gotham chasing clues while playing a "Saw-like" game. Overall the package is entertaining enough to recommend, even if one has to clear an entire afternoon or evening to digest it all and the setup at the very end of the movie promises a sequel that could live up to the well-rounded entry we have here.

The Batman is a near three hours of delicious and dark crime noir. It is bleak and thrilling. Dealing with a Batman that's new to the mask and the vigilante life, it strays from the exploration that former iterations have delivered.

The Batman knows what it is and the direction by Matt Reeves straitly sticks to it. The Batman delivers stunning cinematography and styling, with a delicious score by Michael Giacchino.

The themes (of class, wealth, inequality and PTSD) that The Batman delves into are handled carefully.

A good story, direction, cinematography and action choreography would be nothing if the cast isn't brilliant, and the cast of The Batman is nothing short of brilliance. The broody and contemplative Batman is balanced with a flirty and sensual Catwoman, and the villain in the Riddler is malign, twisted and sinister.

The Batman is a riveting start at Matt Reeves and Robert Pattinson's iteration of the titular character, and should leave audiences wanting more from this Batman.

I enjoyed the main storyline for the most part with John Turturro as Carmine Falcone, Colin Ferrell (completely unrecognizable) as The Penguin and Zoe Cravitz does fine as Catwoman. I also can't forgot Jeffery Wright as Gordon, who does a great job and adds to the movie greatly.

All in all if you're a Batman fan you definitely need to check it out. It's not an all-time great Bat-flick but its worthy of praise and and even if you're not a comic book fan a good thriller with some top notch performances.

There is no better way than to start 2023 than listening to Robert Pattinson mumble something about fear and vengeance to nobody at all again. Possibly the darkest interpretation of Batman we've ever had, and I don't think anybody is complaining. Matt Reeves takes inspiration from basically any David Fincher film you could think of to create a gripping and intense film that explores Gotham in a new way. Instead of creating an ultra-realistic city, like Christopher Nolan, or an ultra-cartoonish city like Tim Burton, Mett Reeves builds a dark and grim city - much like something out of Se7en. The Batman tears almost every layer of cartoonish fun away, and replaces it with psychological thriller and crime noir. And it pulls it off in magnificent fashion. While Pattinson's Bruce Wayne is not on the level of Christian Bale, his Batman strives to new lengths and achieves something nobody else could have done. His sombre and brooding performance as Batman stands out in a film full to the brim of outstanding performances.

The soundtrack adds to the moodiness of this film, with Nirvana's "Something In The Way" seemingly now the theme song of Gotham. It's hard to decide whether the use of that song is as good as the score though. We've always known Michael Giacchino is a master in his craft, but I have a feeling this could later become known as his magnum opus. An absolute robbery from the academy by the way. As I've said before, it's to decide whether this is actually better than The Dark Knight, but even if it isn't as good, it absolutely comes as close as anything else. The costumes and makeup department had their work cut out here, but they certainly delivered. The mix of CGI and practical effects absolutely works here, and I'm sure this will hold up many years from now. Despite being a new take on batman, this really is faithful to the comic books, bringing us the detective batman in a fresh light. Although this is set at the start of batman's career, it's not an origin story. As much as I like origin stories, this excels because Matt Reeves knows and accepts the people watching this as not stupid. No need to have flashbacks to Wayne's parents death - he knows that we already know what happened. The prime example of this is in one of the first scenes, when Batman is investigating a crime scene and he sees the son of the victim. All we needed was a sorrowful look and we understood his feelings.

Verdict: 🏆 97%

It came across as too much of a The Dark Knight wannabe, plots after plots, explosions after explosions, madness after madness..... But let me share WHY "The Dark Knight" is on whole different universe of quality (Chris Nolan aside). It has layers to it, development of the story. The Joker didn't single-handedly set all his plans RIGHT AT THE GET GO. He had to create layers of chaos, destroy many people and groups to grow his legend and force the mob to bend to his will and work with him. And Bruce Wayne/Batman had to burn bridges and be as ruthless as him in order to defeat The Joker and save Gotham, and then some,.... became an Outcast at the end. It was good story telling and Heath Ledger was so convincingly MAD, CHAOTIC and EVIL that he'd give you nightmares for weeks.

The Batman on the other hand, gave you a SUPPOSED same level genius, madness and chaos in The Riddler. Sure, they introduced many other characters from the Original Batman comic stories, but they were shallow, without much focus or character development. AND the real problem was... The Riddler ALREADY had ALL his plot and plan in place BEFORE the movie even began. It was ALL plotted, disaster equipment ALREADY IN PLACE, and BOOM!, no one knew and no one came close to discover anything until everything has happened, and if The Riddler haven't already planned it to be caught, no one would even discover who he is. and Boom, BOOM, BOOOOOM! Layers after layers of chaos happening one after another without so much as a development to HOW those Chaos came about. ALL ALREADY IN PLACE. And grand finale of another 30 minute of chaotic fight sequence where The Batman with very little help defeats all the baddies. 

In The Dark Knight, many things had to happen to lead to its conclusions, for example, the Ferry portion, where the the people of Gotham CHOSE not to kill the other, not to pull the trigger and leave the destruction if any to the perp, not falling into The Joker's plan. In The Batman, it's just boom, Boom, BOOM.... no control whatsoever, such shallow PLOT development. 

I think t he biggest sin is that they TRIED SO HARD to be The Dark Knight, but in my book, failed miserably. Also, I don't like OR dislike the actors/artists in this movie. I KNOW WHO they are, but have neither positive nor negative feel about them. They sort of played the character "Well" I guess, but nothing stood out. They also seem to lack chemistry, to me. Had The Batman NOT PRETEND to be The Dark Knight so hard, instead gone with another method, perhaps I would've enjoyed it more. Hence even more, not one to be watch on a flight.

The Batman surprised me. The close to 3 hour run time was surprising. Robert Pattinson's performance as Batman was surprisingly good, even though it wasn't necessarily memorable. Seeing the Penguin get a complete make over surprised me, but maybe that's just because Danny DeVito's interpretation of the role is so iconic that it it's also impossible for me to associate anyone else with the role. The intermingling of superhero and and Goodfellas style mafia drama was also unexpected. The Batman is by no means a perfect movie and it has its weak parts, such as the plot being quite linear and neither Batman himself, Zoë Kravitz in her role as Catwoman or any of the villains being all that memorable. Will we remember Paul Dano as The Riddler in 20 years time, or Colin Farrell as the Penguin? Perhaps not is the answer, as much as I was dumbfounded upon first finding out that Farrell was actually the Penguin. Having said that, there is a certain flow to the movie that kept me enthralled and engaged, and this feeling only increased as the flicked got closer to its climax, and this is the reason for the 3.5 star rating.

An ambitious film that captures its goal of a gritty, ultra realistic, crime thriller version of Batman. It is enjoyable largely because of this unique vision. 

The Batman shares more in common with the contemporary urban crime style of Frank Miller's "Year One," and less in common with the popcorn action realism of Nolan's Dark Knight trilogy. Yet with this film, we are miles and miles away from Tim Burton's goofy, gothic iteration of the iconic caped crusader. And perhaps that's where this movie falters. It is a little bit too committed to its tone. It is all darkness, without a speck of light. And while that ambition is respectable, ultimately it lacks the much needed levity of Burton and Nolan's films. 

The character development of the titular hero is also severely lacking. We find out little about him at all, other than the fact that he is like a My Chemical Romance version of Bruce Wayne and a very inexperienced, more vulnerable presentation of the character we know and love.

Paul Dano absolutely crushes this uncharacteristically frightening take on The Riddler. 

And the movie is far too long and meandering. 

So it is an ambitious, respectable start but it is seriously flawed and a little too committed to its crushingly macabre atmosphere.

I think that the Batman movies that try to be silly are better than the ones that try to dark and edgy. The LEGO Batman Movie is hilarious and I re-watch it all the time. This movie however is very good. The cinematography is beyond incredible. The music is awesome. The acting is beyond compare. The scene directing is just perfect. When Batman first came in, I truly felt like something amazing was happening before my eyes. It was so powerful. This film actually does dark and edgy well. The shots are just memorable, and I still remember them. The story is written pretty well, while still having flaws. But overall this film does so much that excites you. I walked out of this theater and immediately knew what my new favorite superhero movie was. I highly recommend you to watch this movie. An original take on 'vengeance', the film's noir-tone and shadowy vibe feel just right with introducing the new Batman. Batman himself is dark, ominous, and compelling, feared by criminals and a force of reckoning. The action scenes are a sight of beauty and awe. Pattison also does a great job with the new portrayal of Bruce. The film excels in all these areas. It struggles, however, in falling victim to superhero tropes and lack of depth in its main characters, amongst an excessive run-time. Despite a progressive storyline, it seems unsure at times, and gives way to predictable 'superhero' cliches at times (IE the love interest). We also rarely get a feel of who Bruce Wayne really is, and don't get deep enough into the minds of Penguin, or even The Riddler. With the Zodiac inspiration, one might expect us to get a more intimate psychological view of the twisted menace terrorizing Gotham, yet we do not. And the Penguin is not much of a character at all. Perhaps in the sequel we will get to uncover more character depth, and see more of The Batman obliterating Gotham's seedy underbelly.

I thought the movie would somewhat live up to the bar that was set when Christopher Nolan’s Dark Knight trilogy had set over a decade ago portraying Batman as a caped crusader we all needed. At the time no one expected much based on the previous takes on the worlds great detective from Batman, Batman Returns, Batman Forever, and Batman and Robin. I thought Batman vs Superman could have had a better story than what was portrayed. After seeing this movie my take away from it is that it’s not better than the first portrayals of Batman, a little better than Batman vs Superman and no where close to the dark knight trilogy. How Gotham city was portrayed as a cesspool of crime and corruption was accurate to the comic books. The portrayal of Bruce Wayne as a dark depressed billionaire playboy comes nowhere near how Batman is to be portrayed. Bruce Wayne is supposed to be happy care free playboy billionaire with Batman as a dark and vengeful superhero. Both being portrayed as the same makes me wonder how no one in the city figured it out that they’re one in the same. Plus it did not seem as if they feared Batman seeing how a drug deal went on in front of him and the criminals not thinking twice about it. Even flying in a wing suit instead of using his cape like in Batman Begins and The Dark Knight makes you wonder why have a cape at all. The fact that Batman had to think about catwomans offer to conduct deeds unbefitting to his character leaves disappointment on why Batman was born in the first place and the promise he made the day he was born on that very bad day. Penguins appearance is a much better improvement from Batman Returns. However portraying the riddler as somewhat of a good guy vigilante instead of a villain shows a very poor direction for the character. Even with his costume it does not bring the riddler to life of the movie villain many of us had admired for many years when he was introduced in the comics. Overall the movie has an accurate portray of Gotham but goes into disappointment on its presentation of its characters.

I have quite a few thoughts on the latest Batman franchise installment, but I'll start with my overall feelings on the film:  It is long, which could pose a problem to some.  The length didn't necessarily bother me personally.  I hardly felt the runtime.  With that said, I do believe it could have been trimmed, tighter in some places.  It is darker than other Batman films, but not dark enough in my opinion (speaking to the tone and atmosphere, not the lighting (though that too is a bit on the dark side)).  What Matt Reeves has done with the character here, I quite like (emphasis on detective work and the seniority of Batman (2 years in versus just started or seasoned/old Batman).  Overall I felt The Batman was quite good (-surprising considering the saturation of this character in pop culture and film in the last decades).  I think that's why this installment works for me, it gives a side, albeit small, of this character that we haven't seen a lot of (detecting and fledgling but not new).  In my opinion, this film gives us the best Batman reveal/introduction I've ever seen.  Complaints:  I mentioned it previously, but the film was going for a darker, noir-ish atmosphere and story- I believe it should've either stuck with not showing darker scenes or circumstances or leaned heavily into them (as opposed to some grey middle road).  I'm not looking for really bloody or gory films per se, but the way some scenes are handled in the film gives it a bit of a neutered feel (and in some cases actually took me out of the movie).  In conclusion- The Batman is a film not without it's flaws (runtime, for some, "tip-toeing" around darker elements and market saturation), but overall (and again, surprisingly) I found myself really enjoying the movie.  Matt Reeves hasn't let me down so far and I'm excited to see what other fresh elements he'll bring to the table with this character as this new Batman series continues.

The Batman is a must see for die hard Batman fans. Matt Reeves crafted a stylish, grungy, neo-noir detective story that fully delves into the psychology of the Batman character. Robert Pattinson is by far the most comic accurate portrayal of the caped crusader. We are finally getting a detective Batman who goes into crime scenes and investigates his surroundings and most importantly, DOESN'T KILL. Setting Batman's character into year two and having him learn from his mistakes by becoming a beacon of hope instead of vengeance was a brilliant move by Matt Reeves. I thought that Bruce Wayne being portrayed as a loner was a very interesting take on the character and fully made sense in the context of the story, but I do hope that he does become more of an extrovert in future installments. I also loved the fact that the Waynes aren't perfect and have made mistakes in their lives even though they are still good people. Paul Dano gives a chilling performance as a new take on the Riddler and him being inspired by Batman in a cruel and twisted way is something that we haven't seen a lot before and works wonderfully. Everyone else did a great job as their characters as well and fully complemented Batman's story. Greg Fraiser did a phenomenal job with the cinematography, and Michael Giacchino proved to us again that he has the potential to be the next John Williams with his score. I do think the backstory behind the Wayne's shady actions should've been explored a little more and I thought that the Joker cameo at the end was cool, but kind of derivative. Overall, it's a perfect Batman movie and a near perfect cinema experience. I would give it a 9.5/10 but RT doesn't allow that.

There is a lot that is amazing about this movie that I want to talk about, but this isn't a forum website so I'm just gonna talk about the really good stuff. Firstly, Robert Pattinson was awesome in this role and the character of Batman in general. I like how they finally write him being this very intelligent detective solving a mystery while still having that savagery nature of a vigilante. It was also a great writing choice to set the time of where Batman has just started his career, so we get to see him make mistakes and adapting from them. Oh and the score slaps hard, I mean this is Michael Giacchino were talking about here so you know its gonna be epic. The Riddler was a great villain and had a good motivation behind his plans, but I kinda wish we had more time with The Penguin, I really like how they made him more of this mob gang leader than a mutant human hybrid (don't take this the wrong way, I still love Danny DeVito's Penguin). I guess the car chase makes up for that, and speaking of which, one of the best choreographed car chases I have seen since Baby Driver and probably the best Batmobile in my opinion. Lastly, I like to point out that I was so happy that this was a noir type film than a typical superhero action flick, don't get me wrong Nolan's Dark Knight trilogy is timeless but this had a unique style of pacing, writing, and choreography that I recommend this to anybody who likes the character Batman, or detective films in general.

Batman's "rise" ends up being his detriment to the character as a whole. It's clear that his incompetency is supposed to mirror the Year One narrative, but the script is idiotic and you end up finding out that this is actually year 2 and this isn't his first villain, yet Batman knows absolutely nothing about the criminal underbelly, how Gotham operates, what Wayne Industries is even about, and all his vigilantism is apparently tazing gangbangers in slums. 
You may say that this is the point. This is why there is no discernible difference between Bruce and Batman. There is no mask; he is just obsessed. But obsessed with what? Travis Bickle quickly realized that beating up pimps would not result in the removal of scum from the streets. Yet the "greatest detective" can't figure out who runs who, and needs the Riddler's trail of breadcrumbs? You can cuss on Zoe Kravitz's "privileged white men" line, but in the context of this movie, she is right. And Bruce is one of them. He knows nothing and is easily shamed into realizing that this is a millionaire's hobby in between his Nirvana sessions and another 30 cars pile up, chasing not even a criminal but a lead. Consider me subverted.

I was wary of Zoe Kravitz as Catwoman believing her to have won this job via nepotism due to her stepfather. But I am happy to say that I was wrong, and do one better and say that she is the BEST actress to play the role. She doesn't physically resemble the character like some of her predecessors but she is more hard-hitting and emotionally stronger than all of them ever were. I enjoyed how this depicted the Riddler as a serial killer instead of the goofy killer/thief with a gimmick of riddles and puzzles. Ever since Christopher Nolan rebooted Batman in 2005, films starring the caped crusader have, for better or worse, focused on the dark and brooding nature that's endemic to the character. With The Batman, long gone are the days of flash colours, bat nipples & cheesy one liners. This is a serious film, impactful, memorable and impossible to take your eyes off. It's a very stripped back, down to earth movie, not rely on fancy special effects or over-elaborate set pieces. The characters don't spend their time trying to sound smart or out quip each other, they talk like regular people. The action, while not like anything you'll to see on a day-to-day basis, is very grounded and believable. The premise of a man dressing up in a costume to fight crime is treated with just the right amount of sincerity and gravitas. Robert Pattinson, an incredibly talented actor who's successful broken free from the sparkly vampire role many thought would define his career forever, spends more than 80% of his screen time not as Bruce Wayne, but as the caped crusader. He's not a billionaire playboy or hapless company owner, he's a dedicated crime fighter who only seems comfortable when he's donned the cowl and black makeup. As many have remarked, the film is more of a detective story than it is a superhero movie, and that's great. Rather than trying to outdo what previous instalments have done, Reeves has taken a character we're all familiar with and presented him in a different way. He's essentially a sleuth, a cop with more gadgetry and much less red tape, chasing down a criminal who is terrorising the city while also dealing with unsavoury characters from a seedy underworld. Paul Dano's Riddler is, sadly, too close to Ledger's Joker to not invite comparisons, and while his performance is great, there's nothing about his motivation or behaviour that's especially unique. The 3-hour runtime was daunting, but most of it passed by in a flash because I was so invested in what was going on. Sadly, the film loses steam in the 3rd act. There's still some interesting things going on, but it feels like the film built to an organic climax, then struggled to find anywhere to go afterwards. But there's a reason people are calling this the next great Batman film. Its intense, its epic in scale, has a beautiful aesthetic, likeable characters and a killer lead performance. A sequel is apparently in the works, and if its anywhere near as good as this, I'll be first in line to see it.

Throughout his film career, Director Matt Reeves ("Let Me In," Planet of the Apes series) has explored a variety of issues:  the sense of being "other," the corrosive effects of alienation and whether the desire for vengeance is an integral part of human nature.  "The Batman" covers this territory, too.
Co-written by Reeves and Peter Craig ("The Town,"  "The Hunger Games: Mockingjay"), this film begins when Bruce Wayne/Batman (Robert Pattinson) has been a vigilante crime fighter for two years.  After the Mayor of Gotham City is brutally murdered, Batman works with Lieutenant Gordon (Jeffrey Wright) to identify the killer and uncover his motivation.  Along the way, Batman is required to confront the corruption of Gotham, where city officials are much more interested in self-dealing than improving the metropolis.  Eventually, he discovers that the core of the civic corruption may be closer to home than he thought.
The cast is excellent.  In addition to Wright and Paul Dano as The Riddler, John Turturro makes a charismatic appearance as crime boss Carmine Falcone, Peter Sarsgaard has a brief, explosive role as the corrupt District Attorney and Colin Farrell, unrecognizable beneath prosthetics and a fat suit, is a criminal-in-training as The Penguin.  Zoe Kravitz is a sexy Selina Kyle/Catwoman with her own troubling past to explore. (She apparently prepped for this role by voicing the Catwoman role in 2017's "The Lego Batman Movie.")  I hope that everybody who remains alive will reappear in later episodes of this intended trilogy.  
With this first installment, Reeves has taken the Batman franchise in a very different direction from its predecessors.  His goal appears to be exploring the depths of film noir (cynical heroes, stark/dark lighting, intricate plotting, and existential issues).  This Batman is a brooding loner driven by vengeance, but self-aware enough to journal his thoughts, writing to give voice to his misgivings about life and his role in it, since there is nobody around to talk to.  After "The Lighthouse," this is a relatively upbeat role for Pattinson.
Two things about this Batman don't work.  First, the venal corruption of public officials is so consistent that the viewer eventually assumes that every character's sole motivation is self-interest.  That's too cynical, even for me.  Second, as The Riddler's followers prepare for the film's climactic scene, they debate online what type of weaponry to deploy.  For me, observing an online chat where disgruntled terrorists debate "what gauge" rifles to deploy was art imitating life much too closely.
This Batman is sober, somber but still very worthwhile.  It forcefully confirms the thesis that power always corrupts.

Unlike 'The Joker', 'The Batman' has the moral clarity to clearly define the villain as a villain. The Riddler is a psychopath and a terrorist, and his legitimate grievances about his sad lot in life, with their root in the corruption and criminality of Gotham's elite, don't change that fact. 'The Joker' can't resist the temptation to give its sympathy to its main character, making that film morally compromised.

'The Batman' instead gives a firm basis for Batman's famous rule against killing, for once you take the step of passing mortal judgment on those you deem guilty, the urge develops its own momentum. For the Riddler, the city elites and crime bosses are only at the top of the list, but everyone else in Gotham is complicit and therefore fair game.

Batman's restraint makes him not a villain, but an antihero. Though the film puts too fine a point on it, Bruce Wayne realizes that his initial passion for vengeance is expressed in its logical extreme by monsters like the Riddler. The Batman stands just on the far side of legality, as a vigilante, but that cardinal rule is how he maintains the balancing act, without becoming exactly what he hates.

To me the Selina Kyle character had more charisma than the Batman, especially when the Batman was in his Bruce Wayne alter ego.

Then we have the Riddler. Compared to the charismatic villains that we have come to expect he is just a sad little psychopath with a bunch of equally sad fanatical internet followers.

Now, all of this would have worked great if it had been a movie about some, unspecified, vigilante. The movie is really well done. One of The Best Batman Movies EVER!

In this movie, Batman encountered several obstacles and adversaries throughout the film, whether it was the primary antagonist, The Riddler, or the side villain, the Joker Gang, who emerged at the film's outset. In this movie, director Matt Reeves demonstrates the many tactics utilised to represent Batman as a hero in a realistic world, a concept that parallels Christopher Nolan's The Dark Knight Trilogy's treatment of superheroes. Also, Reeves portrays The Riddler as a character who is inevitably wrecked by the city and its civilisation, which reminds people of another DC film, Todd Philips' Joker. 

However, the film's central theme is the transformation from darkness to light, or crime to justice. 

The film deliberately mixes the good and the evil as a similar concept before breaking them apart at the end — a very smart move for Reeves to confuse the audience before revealing the real concepts as this action creates a much deeper impact on the audience. 

Reeves conveys this main message by using the transition of colour from unsaturated to saturated, or darkness to light to contract evil with justice. 

A great example is in the scene of the murder of the mayor, he is watching television in the opening scene when The Riddler, featuring Edward Nashton, comes behind him and assaults him from behind, forcing the mayor to fall to the ground while The Riddler repeatedly strikes the mayor in the head with a carpet tool, executing him. The whole area was submerged in darkness. There was little light and crime occurred in the dark, which is an indicator of injustice (crime). The whole scenario sequence was filmed impeccably, from a camera behind The Riddler to a camera on the ground, which shows the blood-stained carpet tool as The Riddler drops it by accident, before walking up to it and picking it up off the ground. The camera pans seamlessly from scene to scene, unveiling The Riddler's horrific mask. The filmmaker also included sounds of The Riddler breathing to add to the already terrifying moment. Finally, the Riddler was apprehended and incarcerated in Arkham Asylum. Another allusion to the notion is that crime will always surface and justice will always arrive. 

Furthermore, at the close of Carmine Falcone's appearance, Batman catches him as he is exposed to the light and the police. The light was a symbol of justice, and Falcone would be held accountable for all the wrongdoings he perpetrated in this film—torturing women and committing other crimes in the past.

Throughout the film, the director's colour used to shift from cold to warm, implying that Gotham, a city rife with crime, is ready to renew, redefine, and commit itself to justice; a true indication that Gotham is ready to change and turn for the better following the devastation caused by the Riddler in this film.  Though enemies would continue to return in the future, Batman established faith in this city, something in which the citizens of Gotham could believe, just as God created faith in the Christians. 

Another clue is the portrayal of Batman's parallelism between terror and hope. In the scene where the Joker Gang chases down a guy on the verge of being assaulted at a train station, they were then alarmed by the sound of footsteps. They shifted their gaze to the shadows as a figure began to emerge. The Joker Gang made fun of this Man-Bat figure as it's Halloween and no one believes that a man dressed as a bat is going to do them any harm. The Joker Gang's leader approached him as the leader struck the first punch. Batman grabs it and slams him down with 10 strong punches. As Batman rose to his feet, the Joker Gang stood transfixed, and then the first battle scene started. Batman defeats around 10 individuals while rescuing the guy from a beating. The whole action is filmed from several camera angles to convey how the Joker Gang members might feel while battling Batman. The sequence encapsulates the villains' terror for Batman and demonstrates how it develops in their thoughts. Again, justice was done in a far more visible manner than it would have been in the shadows. 

Additionally, the similarity between Batman and the Riddler provides insight into this paradox. Batman, AKA Bruce Wayne, is the film's icon of justice, while The Riddler, AKA Edward Nashton, is the film's symbol of criminality. Both characters in this film spy on individuals. While The Riddler is watching the mayor for an opportunity to attack, Batman is following Catwoman, an anti-hero, seeking information and an answer to a crime. Both individuals watch others changing the world by their perceptions of what is just and righteous. 

Toward the film's end, the Riddler-inspired criminal, dressed as the Riddler, embarks on a mission to assassinate the new mayor to fulfil The Riddler's stated aim – "Unmask the truth." At the scene's conclusion, we glimpse one of the criminals. When asked who he is, he responds that he is vengeance – a well-known Batman catchphrase. This scene re-defines what justice and fairness are in this film and shows Batman what some people have become due to his actions. It's a true point turner and a philosophical point in the film. 

The Batman movie challenges us to reconsider our idea of justice and if what we believe to be justice is indeed justice. 

In this film, Matt Reeves has caught the spirit of both the antagonist and the hero. The Riddler, starring Paul Dano, depicts a less family-friendly riddler and a more cunning adversary. Batman, played by Robert Pattinson, reveals the true nature of vengeance and the power of terror in his hands. This figure exemplifies the words from Batman Begins, "As a man, I'm flesh and blood." I can be ignored. I can be destroyed. But as a symbol? As a symbol, I can be incorruptible. I can be everlasting." This is an outstanding Batman movie with the potential for a trilogy.

After 10 live action Batman films Matt Reeves The Batman had a tall task in front of itself. How can you bring something new to the table after so many other adaptations of this character? For the most part The Batman succeeded in keeping him fresh by taking an approach that hasn't really been explored in previous movies. In comics Batman is known to be the world's greatest detective yet in the films they barely use his detective skills. Jumping right into year two without needing to do an origin story was also a smart approach as we the audience already know who batman and bruce wayne is, and know his background. I don't think I can sit through another edition of seeing Martha and Thomas wayne getting murdered in an alleyway. It's been done to death and I'm glad we didn't have to revisit it here . Robert Pattinson does a great job as the dark knight and has the longest screentime in the costume than any other actor has before. Batman is front and center and barely any time is spent with Bruce Wayne out of costume. This movie is perhaps the darkest batman movie to date, its gritty and takes a realistic approach even more than the Nolan trilogy. Although this approach may be off putting for some as even I wish they could find a happy medium and lean a little more into the fantastical nature of the Batman villan gallery. The riddler is a complete psychotic serial killer acting more like Jigsaw from the saw films and less like the riddler we know in comics. I liked Paul Danos performance  in this but it was a bit jarring to watch. Couldn't help but telling myself this isnt my Riddler. Collin Farrell as The penguin who is almost unrecognizable underneath all that makeup also gives a great performance. Jeffrey Wright is a natural fit to play commissioner Gordon. It's a solid cast and great acting from all. The fights deliver brutality like Arkham knight video games did. Although there is less action that you think there would be in a Batman film. There is some pacing issues and things kinda drag a little bit. Perhaps it's a little too self indulgent with a nearly 3hr running time. Im also a bit offended at the fact that Justice league snyder cut wasn't allowed a 3hr film for theaters yet here we are just a few years removed from that fiasco with a 3hr batman movie. This isn't the masterpiece that The Dark Knight was but for a first go round it's a valiant effort. It doesn't quite reach the epic heights it's clearly trying to reach for but its almost there. I think the third act kind of betrays what comes before it. I realize that it's a commercial films made for a massive audience but the final climax may not have been necessary, the film could have still had the same impact and shorter run time. Im intrigued in what a sequel will have to offer.

For a creative film like this, you must praise the good qualities of what made this film so unique. The costume designs and makeup for Batman, Catwoman, Penguin, and Riddler were all pretty cool in their own unique ways. While I did not care for Robert Pattinson's performances as Bruce Wayne, I do give praise to Zoë Kravitz and Paul Dano. As expected for a DC film let alone a superhero film, you are able to see a lot of action sequences and visual effects. The Batman has a lot of epic sequences and visuals. Last but not least, Michael Giacchino deserves some praise with his original musical score that is really unique that makes your heart race. It is an original, creative, neo-noir film created by the brilliant Matt Reeves who gave us something that is original and impressive.

Bruce Wayne, the young billionaire, played by Robert Pattinson doesn't match with his tough Batman. In other hand, Paul Dano incarnates a frantic and disturbed Riddler, nothing else than a distorted reflection in a broken mirror of Vengeance. Selina Kyle, Gordon, Alfred and other regular allies of Batman are around supporting him as usual, but The Penguin played by Colin Farrel, deserves an honorable mention. Also, the use of Nirvana's  Something in the way song in the start of the movie sets up the mood and the tone of red and black Gotham City of The Batman.

After another watch I can finally comprehend and write a proper review so here we go:

Score: Michael Giacchino does a phenomenal job with the score, creating tension, suspense and payoff all in one single track. The ambience built up by the gritty atmosphere is really good, and I like the religious and classical music played whenever the Riddler is present as it makes him feel even more warped as a twisted view on a Messiah. Also, one of my favourite songs is in this (Something In The Way) so added points there.

Cinematography: There are also a lot of biblical references in the shots, with references to Messiah's, The Seven Deadly Sins and Religious Quotes like the Ivory Tower reference (the shot is looking down on them). They also use colour or the lack there of to create atmosphere and make Gotham really gritty. It also makes The Batman more bat like due to the darkness or blurring they use to obscure him and make him seem more intimidating. The colour is usually pure white (or faded) or Red when it's used, with red referencing to the blood on their hands in the Iceberg Lounge that they cover up, and the white referencing religion once again as it's used in Church and to represent the Riddler as even more of a twisted Messiah; the white is also slightly faded to represent the tainted purity and how nothing, even religion, is innocent to the sins and punishment. They use close up shots to trap Bruce as Batman in his emotional state as he can't decide which of his two personalities to choose as Batman is slowly consuming his life. When he's fully Bruce, the camera pans out and he's always at the centre of attention, as his anxiety would likely take over his thoughts; When he's fully Batman, he's always off centre as he wouldn't want to be the centre of attention considering he's meant to be hiding in the shadows.

Acting: Robert Pattinson gives a career best as Bruce and Batman, as he manages to create a unique Bruce Wayne separate from the Playboy Philanthropist we've grown accustomed to, and also as a faithful representation of the Earth-1 Bruce he's based more closely off of. His Batman is also really good, and he's pretty intimidating with his physique and gritty voice, but whilst he's the best portrayal so far there's nothing super about it. However, Paul Dano is excellent in portraying a sadist, and his commitment to the role is extremely commendable and shows how versatile and brilliant his acting prowess is. Everything from his little to major actions make him so much more believable, and much like Robert Pattinson his voice is really well implemented to create a much more threatening character. Jeffrey Wright plays really well off of Robert and they have great chemistry with a very believable friendship and alliance that grows throughout the movie. Zoe Kravitz is also excellent and she's definitely a rising star if her career with this and Kimi continue to grow.

Plot: The plot is really the shining point, and it does something that many have faltered whilst attempting: the three villain formula as The Riddler is still the central threat, Penguin is a very strong side villain who expands the crime aspects and he really does show a lot about the grittiness of Gotham. Carmine also serves well as a secondary villain but he's more of a catalyst for the climax and the setup of the Penguin TV show we're getting, even though he's played by the phenomenal John Turturro. I like how Matt Reeves focuses more on the crime neo-noir aspects rather than the formula that both the MCU and DCEU follow as that would've killed this. The detective aspects rival that of Zodiac, Se7en, and Chinatown and are very clearly inspired by those films and that's a good film as their approach is very successful. It's also surprisingly goofy with some unexpected jokes like the "Thumb Drive" one that still gets me everytime.

The Action: Batman doesn't kill. Thank God. For real though the car chase is the best in cinema and it gives me chills everytime hearing that engine roar. The fight scenes are all creative, and a minor bonus but I love when they incorporate the cape into his weaknesses as it'd realistic for it to be tossed around in combat. The hallway fight is a standout with beautiful visuals and a creative premise that was executed amazingly. 

The best Scene: Will always be one of the final ones: when Batman is leading the civilians to safety in the water. Batman's character arc of realising that he needs to be a symbol of hope rather than fear is emotionally powerful and compelling, and it's everything that makes me love Batman in a single scene. The icing on the cake also has to be the narration over the top, as Robert Pattinson makes it all that better, even with the Nirvana song.

The one nitpick: The Joker scene is very rushed and feels forced for the sake of exposition, and they took out the other scene with Barry Keoghan's Joker and that one makes this a little better as it convinces me he'll be an actually good addition to the sequel.

Overall: Matt Reeves killed it with this and I hope he continues to make this a franchise as I'd watch every single one he makes, continue killing it!

The Batman is the latest remake/reboot about the Caped Crusader. It's quite well-made and well-written. It's grim, dark and grounded - reminiscent of Nolan's Batman movies. My friend said she looked like Jim Lee's version of Catwoman from the Hush comic book. Paul Dano's performance as a terrifying Riddler was just terrific. Everyone was saying that Collin Farrell looked so convincing in prosthetic makeup that you couldn't tell it was him. Jeffrey Wright and Andy Serkis were also great as James Gordon and Alfred, respectively. I love the cinematography and sound editing of the movie. It was quite an audio-visual treat. That new theme which played whenever Batman enters a scene sets the right mood. I expected the film to be dark and grim, which was appropriate. Everyone seems to love the fact that this new outing focused more on Batman as the brilliant detective that he is. Solving crimes and unravelling secrets, yet not short on action. It's a welcome change from the usual action-packed, CGI-laden superhero flicks. Overall, I love this new remake/reboot and I do hope this is a start of a new trilogy.

I haven't seen any Batman movies starring Ben Affleck and I still felt like this one was too soon. That being said, The Batman didn't just make another "gritty superhero" movie, but created a much more realistic cast of characters and villains — I was even surprised they gave Batman (Robert Pattinson) bat ears and a cape for his outfit. "Catwoman" (Zoe Kravitz) just has lots of cats and slinks through the night like a feline, but never actually goes by the name of meows or some shit like that. "The Penguin" (Colin Farrell) just has a large, crooked nose and wears a tuxedo; "The Riddler" (Paul Dano) is a dark web psychopath, eons removed from Jim Carrey's characterization from 1995. While still a billionaire, the Bruce Wayne of Matt Reeves' movie is a soft-spoken recluse — Pattinson's got the chin, he's got the voice, is he going to get the girl? Keeping with the trend of movies in the past 10 years or so, the budding romance here takes a backseat to much of the plot, but doesn't disappear completely, which is where it should be. So often, romantic storylines are shoved into otherwise entertaining plots, which derails the experience. Like we are slowly introduced to each character, piece by piece, we are also presented with Gotham City, a villain in its own right — it's hard to argue that the villains of the Batman universe aren't products of their environment. Paul Dano's "Riddler" is the villain for 2022 and I was totally expecting a nod to his inspiration from Joaquin Phoenix's "Joker" (from Joker), but alas, these are different universes (try and keep up). Let's talk "Joker" (Barry Keoghan) — even more so than Batman, I felt like we needed less of a "Joker" portrayal here, but yet again, I was tickled with excitement from his quick appearance and potential one-two punch with "the Riddler" in the next movie. *Side Note* I did watch that deleted scene floating around the interwebs and think Keoghan will make a welcomed addition to the exalted "Joker" brotherhood. Even though it's three hours, the plot does move. However, I didn't fully understand what exactly went wrong and how Batman helped, besides moving people out of the flooding waters like a Coast Guardsman? Moreover, why was "Riddler" so upset? His plan was largely a success, he gained many followers to his cause, and he gave himself up, so it's not as if he was just mad about getting caught. The Batman feels like a solid foundation for a stylish and entertaining series.

This movie is yet another reinvention of Batman, this time both more grounded and more gritty than Nolan's trilogy. It chooses style over convention many times, which could have made the chase scenes hard to follow, for example, but the direction masterfully guides the audience to keep up with the action. Pattinson is good as Bruce Wayne but really shines as Batman, and the script focuses on the intimidatingly silent detective more than the super-human super-rich super-hero. The Riddler's riddles aren't sublime, but they're more than good enough to carry keep the audience intrigued until the answers are revealed. This film's primary sin is its length, clocking in at four minutes shy of three hours, when a deft editor could have trimmed it down by a solid half hour if he had been allowed to do so.

Closest comparison: It's like Batman Begins by way of Joker (2019).

This version of Batman is fresh, new, and very necessary. The movie doesn't take the time to explain the origins of the hero, which serves as a positive, making the movie seem more like an excellently made sequel to a film we've all heard, known, and love. We see a much different, more melancholy Bruce Wayne, who has to deep dive into his past and his parents, but this time with the story heading in a much different direction than the previous iterations of the character. Every main character was multi-dimensional, serving a large role for the plot to play out. While this was a good thing, it did make a bit of the story slightly hard to follow, with the "he did this, then this person responded" conversations being a bit too vague to grasp every detail. But in the end, the basic concept is thought out, compelling, engaging, intense, and fun to watch. The Batman is an action-packed nose dive into detective work and undercover investigating that leaves the audience begging for another mystery for Bruce Wayne to solve.

The first thing I need to say is I really loved Robert Pattinson's portrayal of the caped crusader and the direction of this movie is phenomenal. The movie really takes itself seriously and lets Robert Pattinson be as edgy and broody to the maximum and it really fits the tone. As soon as the movie starts it dives you headfirst into this Gotham and shows the city's shadows and how criminals fear the Batman is lurking in those shadows. It's so interesting to give a POV of how criminals think he could be there and how paranoid it can make a person. The film is long but I don't think it felt too drawn out. It really felt like a 2-hour movie. The acting is really great, the action is spectacular, and the soundtrack is something to behold. Paul Dano does a really great job with Riddler and he does really well portraying the twisted and mental unwellness of the character. Colin Farrel was such an overwhelming presence of humor and was almost unrecognizable in the role and I can't wait to see more.

Clocking in at a whopping two hours and fifty-six minutes, the film begins to meander around a lackluster cat and mouse game infused with sub-plots that could have and should have been either condensed or cut out entirely.  It's shocking to think that there are sequences of the Joker that were cut out of the film, which makes one wonder, how much longer did Reeves intend on the final cut. The fight sequences doesn't push this genre forward in any unique or revolutionary ways and Pattinson and Kravitz's on screen chemistry was non-existent.  The Penguin, played by Colin Farrell, was absolutely jaw-dropping in terms of the actor's transformation.  I didn't realize it was Farrell until the credits.  The Batman can be appreciated by hardcore Batman fans, but for the average viewer, this latest rendition of the Caped Crusader might be a single viewing experience.

The movie has a pretty solid scenario. I liked the idea of having the riddler as the main antagonist, a character not seen in the movies with Christian Bale. However, I found that the costumes weren't very well designed. The riddler has more vibrant colors in the comics or even "Gotham". I found his design unfinished. Furthermore, I found the casting pretty poor, I did not appreciate Robert Pattison in the role of the Batman. Furthermore, Alfred does not look very old. He is supposed to be at least 50 to 60 years old. He looks like he is about 40. The romance developed between Batman and Catwoman is not at all well constructed. In the movie, I feel like they rushed it. Their first kiss made no sense. Bruce Wayne is portrayed as an emo-depressive guy unable to defend himself and a victim of everyone. Finally, Batman is supposed to be a vigilante at the beginning. How is it everyone accepts him being on crime sites when he wants. I understand he is in the end considered a hero by all but people are still supposed to despise him. Gordon is neither chief of police nor commissioner so why doesn't any policeman stand up (like the guy in the beginning) and try to arrest him. I also find that the role of Bruce Wayne in the movie is too little. He is described as the "son of Gotham", yet he only appears at one event in a 3-hour long movie for ten minutes. I found the development of every character very rushed and not at all well constructed. I may seem harsh, however, a huge movie franchise such as batman needs to be very well written and directed. Each character in batman has a story, yet in the movie, none of them were explained. In addition, the movie doesn't follow any series or previous movies so we don't know any backstory as it should have been done.

The tricky thing about reviving a long-lived franchise is, it's always going to be compared to its predecessors. And, as the caped crusader goes, that history is awfully long and speckled. Tim Burton dealt with this when he helmed the 1989 iteration, dodging complaints that it was so fundamentally different from the Adam West camp of twenty years prior. Christopher Nolan fought an uphill battle in overcoming the damage inflicted by Joel Schumacher's missteps. Now, in the wake of Ben Affleck's turn beneath the cowl, Matt Reeves faces a different, but similar fight in justifying his vision of a spandex-clad detective in the crumbling urban decay.

Reeves gives us a younger Batman, less seasoned and polished than the Kilmer/Clooney/Affleck years, but also not a rookie. This isn't an origin story; this bat's reputation has already been established in Gotham and he's fostered a tenuous working relationship with certain members of the police force. He's visible enough to draw the attention of a violent, counter-culture master criminal who addresses hints and clues like love letters and sprinkles them around his prolific crime scenes. But he lacks that grand, accomplished sense of supreme confidence: a patrolman who's still learning his beat, he makes mistakes and takes lessons from them. Actually, he makes a *lot* of mistakes. This Batman is neither impervious in a fight nor unmatched in an intellectual sense. He often seems like he's out of his depth, reacting and improvising to events beyond his control. That can be humanizing, but it also limits his aura. In terms of raw energy and dramatic appearances, this rendition ranks near the bottom. I might even call him dull.

That's a problem with the whole film, in fact. It has inspired and effective moments, isn't demonstrably bad, but constantly feels clinical and lethargic. There's very little dramatic spectacle, so I was never wowed. For all the boastful talk about emphasizing the detective aspect of his character, Batman himself doesn't actually solve much. Alfred cracks most of the riddles, and when he's eventually indisposed, the Riddler complains that his counterpart isn't getting to the answers fast enough. Robert Pattinson's take on the leading role is... okay. He looks the part while in costume, but often overacts, and his take on the brooding Bruce Wayne, as I'd feared, falls on the wrong side of the emo spectrum. Paul Dano's Se7en-influenced Riddler is a fresh reimagining, but the conclusion of his story (or lack thereof) leaves an empty feeling. Hints and implications are dropped all over the place - about Gordon, the Penguin, Catwoman and other noteworthy rogues who shall remain nameless - but none go beyond the level of superficial winks. Batman and Robin's Mister Freeze, for all his cheesy one-liners and bad costume effects, had a more cohesive, satisfying story than any of these characters.

I don't want to give the wrong impression. This isn't a bad effort. I admire its influences, and its chutzpah for wearing them loudly on its chest. Gotham is dark and gritty, its corrupt politicians serving as an appropriate mirror to their real-life counterparts. The costumes and set designs look great. But, in a strange way, I feel that it tries too hard to match the execution of 2019's Joker without really grasping what made that movie tick or why the two should be distinctive. Both are deathly serious, heavily visual, mood-reliant character pieces, but where Joker limits its iris to a small, tight group of characters, The Batman is overwhelmed by its cast. Joaquin Phoenix takes us on a private journey in the former film, and it's meaningful when his arc is resolved. Pattinson, by comparison, never progresses beyond looking mopey in the rain.

The Batman lives up to expectations, with a melodic score, great acting, a compelling and unpredictable plot, impressive directing, memorable dialogue, cinematography that is dark, but doesn't sacrifice visual clarity, and it genuinely feels like a comic book movie, but is still dark and gritty (and that is something you rarely see). But the praises don't stop there, as Batman is actually written exactly how he should be. He gets a satisfying character arc of going from being about vengeance, to being a symbol of hope and inspiration, and he refuses to kill or use guns. The Riddler is also a great character, as he has very complex motives and goals, and Paul Dano delivers an incredible performance. But the best thing about the movie, is the fact that it retreads elements from so many previous superhero films (from both DC and Marvel) that it is actually impressive and unique. The only problems with the feature is that the pacing goes a little to fast in the first hour and some of the characters are underdeveloped.

I know what you're thinking..., or maybe I don't, but I know what I first thought when I heard the news of the film we know today as Matt Reeves' "The Batman" and that was "Not again...." See, the "world's greatest detective's" name has been dragged from comic to screen, from campy to cartoony, and from nostalgia to annoyance. And everyone who seems to know the name of Bruce Wayne and that of his intrepid counterpart, the Batman, seems to have their preferred permutations of their favorite masked vigilante. For some, it may be the comedic stylings of the late Mr. Adam West's self-aware approach to the hero that they let fill their head; for others, it is the more dramatic performance of Mr. Michael Keaton that sent the old drug of nostalgia through their veins, but for myself, it was the bruting, dark performance of Mr. Christian Bale that rested on the skyscraper-mounted gargoyles of my mind. Like most who hold on to the past, I was skeptical of the film, and like most who care to experience the present with an open mind, my views changed the day I sat down in a darkened IMAX and let the sweet sounds of "Ave Maria" fill my ears...

Two hours and fifty-six minutes later, and the world made sense. The birds sang, and the sun shone as I stumbled from the theater's embrace, a changed man; it was as if nature itself was crying out in one voice, "The king is dead. Long live the King!" rightfully forgetting every other film that predated this masterpiece... An exaggeration? Yes, but the film had indeed stirred something inside myself a bit more than your typical blockbuster. You see, the plot: a weaving mystery which felt both fulfilling and enjoyable along the way; the acting: natural; the set design, the makeup, props, and more: entrancing, but the piece that truly tied it all together was the cinematography.

As I have attested, the story is enjoyable, a well-put-together mystery neo-noir with a toe dipped in the superhero pool. Still, without Mr. Reeves' and, the director of photography, Mr. Greig Fraser's masterful cinematography, it would have been just that, enjoyable, not the piece worthy of intercontinental cinema fans' ogling. Books could be filled with tales of woe and praise for this film's unique and fascinating techniques behind the scenes, and, if you will allow me to make an appeal to hypocrisy, libraries could be filled with what I do not know about that elusive art, so I will keep my remarks brief and without too much jargon. The beauty of the cinematography lies with the breathtaking use of "dirting" the lens and making you feel the weight of the moment along with the characters; that, along with gorgeous tracking shots, beautiful lighting, and more, is what makes the film what it is loved for today. There.

"The Batman" is a truly intriguing film, flaws and all. However, I wish not to delve into said flaws as it might spoil the film for those among us who have not yet seen it, I merely wish to say I don't love parts of the story by themselves (namely the last fight and the Batman's seemingly invincible nature), but in the end, each of the said parts works around for the benefit of the plot and the film as a whole. This film is one I believe has the potential to spark great creative change in a seemingly static Hollywood and one I would recommend even to those who are not a fan of the genre. And maybe I don't know what you're thinking, but if you are anything like me, it might have something to do with our old, elusive pal, the Batman, and his many escapades above the towering lights of Gotham and under the limelights of Hollywood.

Here we go again.  Batman is back in "The Batman".  It has most all the elements in place that made the previous Batman movies successful.  That is both a good and bad thing.  The good is that it continues in the vein of what made the Nolan films good.  On the downside, it ends up being compared to those films.  This time Robert Pattinson steps into the role of Bruce Wayne/Batman.  I was surprised how decent he looked the part when in costume.  He tried his best Christiaan Bale growl.  He stumbles when playing the other side.  The decision to make the billionaire a moody, sulking, slacker was not a good one.  Pattinson plays the part like he's trying to channel James Dean.
