The Batman is by far the most faithful to the source material when it comes to live action Batman adaptations. Matt Reeves deeply understands every nuance of the Batman character along with supporting characters such as Selina Kyle, The Riddler, Penguin, Jim Gordon, Carmine Falcone, etc. Robert Pattinson does a phenomenal job as a tormented Batman/Bruce Wayne who shares fantastic chemistry with Selina Kyle/Catwoman played by Zoe Kravitz. The dynamic between Pattinson's Batman and Jeffrey Wright's Jim Gordon brings some much needed levity to the film's ultra dark and gritty tone. Paul Dano delivers an outstanding performance as a radically different version of the Riddler, as does Colin Farrell who is completely unrecognizable as the Penguin. Unlike past live action Batman films, the Batman's narrative relies heavily on the detective aspect of the character which has yet to be explored in full detail. As a result we get an extremely engaging slow burn detective/noir film as opposed to the fast paced action-packed film that we're typically used to with modern comic book movies. That being said, this film is not for everyone. It's also notable that this is by far the most comic-accurate live action iteration of Gotham City to date. The griminess and the history of crime in the city is beautifully displayed in the opening scene and really sets the tone for the rest of the film, which is only further enhanced by Greg Fraser's stunning cinematography and Michael Giacchino's epically haunting score. Overall, The Batman is a PERFECT Batman film that delivers in every single aspect imaginable, and deserves to be placed among one of the greatest comic book movies ever made. (10/10)

Now, I just wished I hadn't heard some people hype it up as much as they did. This was not an epic film to go nuts about. It just wasn't THAT good. It was somewhat unique and different in that it stood alone from the other Batman films. It definitely satisfied in that regard. The ONLY real knock I had was it seemed to be stuck a bit in its pace. I couldn't put my finger on it, but it made the already long film seem a little bit longer than it should. The more I think on it, I realize I didn't like that almost the entire film was dark. Intentionally so and I know that, but ultimately, I think that was a mistake. There were no literal or figurative "windows of light" to allow the viewer to come up for air. I kinda felt beat down by the end. Maybe I'm being overly critical, but it bothered me that I didn't like it more than I did. The bottom line for me is that this was a solid new version of Batman for DC without the complete entertainment value I'm used to in a hero story. Christopher Nolan's version is still my favorite Batman. Overall 8/10 and 👍🏻👍🏻 - go see it on the big screen! In DOLBY if you can! Enjoy!

A Batman movie that actually focuses on Batman and his role in the world is a refreshing take. Aurally, the film has a very distinct and immersive sound. Visually, Gotham is significantly more interesting than Nolan's rendition, but doesn't hold a candle to Burton's. It manages to tie together two separate storylines quite well up to the 2 hour mark, at which point an entirely different movie is suddenly slapped on at no additional charge. The climax of the film is a narrative train wreck that feels rushed in spite of the film's overly long runtime. The overall motif of Batman inspiring other people to take the law in their own hands is an interesting take, and Bruce's words at the end leave me interested in what direction they'll take this iteration of the Bat.

"The Batman" has finally taken us back to the roots of the Caped Crusader, in the way that its dark narrative and frighteningly realistic setting matches Bob Kane's original vision in a way that comics after his time never could.
This film also draws inspiration from the best modern eras of Batman, including the late 70s through the 90s, when creating its overall dark mood. 
Robert Pattinson's fantastic performances as both Bruce Wayne and The Batman are stunning, although he doesn't get much time to shine as Wayne. Zoë Kravitz, Paul Dano and Collin Farrell are fantastic performers, and we get to see their acting in different (and frankly, better) ways than we've ever seen them before. The treatments of both Jim Gordon (Jeffrey Wright) and Alfred Pennyworth (MoCap King Andy Serkis) are very good, but neither characters are given much time to represent their comic counterparts; something that Matt Reeves is sure to remedy for the imminent sequel. Rounding out the cast is the magnificent and legendary John Turturro, with a terrifying and entertaining turn as a classic Batman mob boss. While the more "regular" Batman villains like mobsters and mob bosses have never been properly represented on the Big Screen (apologies to the fans of Christopher Nolan's "Batman Begins" and Tim Burton's "Batman"), Turturro's performance as Carmine Falcone (and Dano's as Edward "The Riddler" Nashton, for that matter), reminds us that evil people don't have to be super-villains to be deadly and menacing.
In conclusion, the Batman is fantastic. From Pattinson's opening monologue, to the constant musical theme of Franz Shubert's "Ave Maria," and to the Biblical imagery that runs throughout the film, Matt Reeves' intended theme is clear: To right the sins of the fathers, we must be willing to sacrifice something of ourselves.

Ever since Christopher Nolan rebooted Batman in 2005, films starring the caped crusader have, for better or worse, focused on the dark and brooding nature that's endemic to the character. With The Batman, long gone are the days of flash colours, bat nipples & cheesy one liners. This is a serious film, impactful, memorable and impossible to take your eyes off. It's a very stripped back, down to earth movie, not rely on fancy special effects or over-elaborate set pieces. The characters don't spend their time trying to sound smart or out quip each other, they talk like regular people. The action, while not like anything you'll to see on a day-to-day basis, is very grounded and believable. The premise of a man dressing up in a costume to fight crime is treated with just the right amount of sincerity and gravitas. Robert Pattinson, an incredibly talented actor who's successful broken free from the sparkly vampire role many thought would define his career forever, spends more than 80% of his screen time not as Bruce Wayne, but as the caped crusader. He's not a billionaire playboy or hapless company owner, he's a dedicated crime fighter who only seems comfortable when he's donned the cowl and black makeup. As many have remarked, the film is more of a detective story than it is a superhero movie, and that's great. Rather than trying to outdo what previous instalments have done, Reeves has taken a character we're all familiar with and presented him in a different way. He's essentially a sleuth, a cop with more gadgetry and much less red tape, chasing down a criminal who is terrorising the city while also dealing with unsavoury characters from a seedy underworld. Paul Dano's Riddler is, sadly, too close to Ledger's Joker to not invite comparisons, and while his performance is great, there's nothing about his motivation or behaviour that's especially unique. The 3-hour runtime was daunting, but most of it passed by in a flash because I was so invested in what was going on. Sadly, the film loses steam in the 3rd act. There's still some interesting things going on, but it feels like the film built to an organic climax, then struggled to find anywhere to go afterwards. But there's a reason people are calling this the next great Batman film. Its intense, its epic in scale, has a beautiful aesthetic, likeable characters and a killer lead performance. A sequel is apparently in the works, and if its anywhere near as good as this, I'll be first in line to see it.

It's a breath of fresh air to Batman's cinematic portrayal and to filmmaking as a whole. I went in thinking "the bar for an interesting Batman film is on the floor" and then left the theater feeling so exhilarated and excited over a character I haven't cared about in decades. 

This film reignited a joy for the process of filmmaking that's been lost to me in recent years. While a number of films that gain publicity are entertaining and fun, many of them feel generally uninspired or forgettable (particularly in anything that isn't the writing or acting). The Batman stays consistent in it's themes and actually utilizes the environment to propel its story in a revivifying way. The city of Gotham actually feels like a place with a history to care about. The combination of the layers of sound and the distinctive lenses used add immensely to the mood and ambiance. The use of lighting accentuates the atmosphere and provides in tone what I usually only notice from the music composition. All of this is able to be interpreted by audiences peripherally without forcing everyone to sit through a boring exposition instead. Truly, there's so much care and thought put into the writing, sound design, cinematography, music composition, lighting and costume/set design that it's palpable. There's so much I could write an essay on it. 

Overall, I wish more film studios would step it up and allow the creative teams to work with more originality to achieve their own unique visions. The Batman might seem long, but it ties up a lot of its loose ends nicely and leaves the audience feeling generally satisfied. It's a good movie to watch for a casual film fan and a great one to watch for a Batman fan.

This Batman takes more than a little inspiration from Nolan's Dark Knight trilogy.
It feels like a spiritual sequel to Batman Begins, starring a sophomore Batman who is still getting used to his vigilantism. The presence of chiaroscuro lighting, a gravelly-voiced hero, and a villain shooting threatening home videos all feel very familiar, though still entertaining.

Pattinson's Bruce Wayne has an oddly emo sensibility, with long hair that falls into his eyes as he says things like "You're not my father, Alfred!" His Batman, however, is an intimidating figure with a mind to match the muscles. Zoe Kravitz's Catwoman is the most three-dimensional take on the character yet. Paul Dano's Riddler is really an original character, bearing more resemblance to the Zodiac killer than the comic book villain. The standout of the cast is Colin Farrell as Penguin, who strikes the perfect balance between camp and menace.

The plot is convoluted, relying heavily on unseen backstory and spinning a mystery that never really pays off. Its biggest weakness, though, is how utterly humorless it is. Gotham is home to the most brooding, sullen people on earth. Its greatest strength is the way it returns to Batman's roots as the world's greatest detective, letting him spend as much time solving puzzles as he does beating up criminals.
Overall, it's a well-made movie but while it doesn't feel stale, it doesn't feel fresh, either.

The attention to detail in the scenes that tour Gotham remind me of the shades of green effect used in the film "The Matrix." With a 3 hour run time, the viewer can experience the bold and well constructed vision of the city. Scenes with combat remind the us that Batman, is in fact, a man. Despite the advantages Bruce Wayne can afford to arm himself with, the struggle for Batman to fight as a one-man army feels calibrated and suspenseful. Colin Farrell's performance as Penguin is probably the most notable in the movie. The much praised makeup is indeed impressive, but more so is the depth of the character. Penguin is both Batman's adversary, and needed resource into the criminal underworld. However, what the film lacks is narrative and vision. Robert Pattinson's performance as Bruce Wayne is competent, but the story is a hot mess. The movie starts as a sort of nod to David Fincher films regarding serial killers, the most obvious being (borderline copying) "Zodiac." A large portion of the movie is dedicated to Batman's work with Selina Kyle "Catwoman." This is perhaps the worst component of the movie. Zoë Kravitz's performance just seems silly. Though the character is written into almost every aspect of the story, none of the revelations that occur as the story unfolds seem worth caring about. Her delivery just isn't unconvincing. This is partly the writing as well. There's the notion of Batman calling himself "vengeance" throughout the film. It wouldn't exactly be a spoiler to say that this is a device in the story to show the character's development. But again, this never really materializes in a convincing or interesting way. The Batman doesn't leave me too excited for its sequel, but this is by no means a bad movie. I don't think I could say a movie that held my attention for such a long runtime is not worth watching. At one point I checked to see how much time was left, and I became excited with I saw I had an hour left to go.

An original take on 'vengeance', the film's noir-tone and shadowy vibe feel just right with introducing the new Batman. Batman himself is dark, ominous, and compelling, feared by criminals and a force of reckoning. The action scenes are a sight of beauty and awe. Pattison also does a great job with the new portrayal of Bruce. The film excels in all these areas. It struggles, however, in falling victim to superhero tropes and lack of depth in its main characters, amongst an excessive run-time. Despite a progressive storyline, it seems unsure at times, and gives way to predictable 'superhero' cliches at times (IE the love interest). We also rarely get a feel of who Bruce Wayne really is, and don't get deep enough into the minds of Penguin, or even The Riddler. With the Zodiac inspiration, one might expect us to get a more intimate psychological view of the twisted menace terrorizing Gotham, yet we do not. And the Penguin is not much of a character at all. Perhaps in the sequel we will get to uncover more character depth, and see more of The Batman obliterating Gotham's seedy underbelly.

Story-wise, it's not quite as complex or clever as I'd hoped and there's not much that hasn't been said before (to be fair, finding something completely new to say can't be an easy task), but it's the way that its told that makes all the difference here: bleak, gritty, and uncompromising, this is Gotham, its villains, and it's Caped Crusader at their darkest (at least in the live-action versions). With clear Fincher vibes, it's a neo-noir thriller/murder-mystery that makes sure not to forget we're dealing with intelligent characters on both sides, it just happens to be that one them dresses up as a bat; that is to say, in many ways, it feels more realistic and grounded than any of the live-action films to come before it, complete with a fantastic cast who give their characters as much gravitas as you can hope for in a comic-book film. Serkis, Turturro, Wright, and a fantastically unrecognisable Farrell all do justice to their respective characters; Dano gives us a superior and creepy version of The Riddler who you can actually take seriously (the abscence of green spandex probably helped); Kravitz is easily the best Catwoman since Pfeiffer; and then, of course, there's Pattinson who brings anger and determination, but also inexperience and doubt to his young Batman giving us, perhaps, the most emotionally fragile version of the character so far. I mean that in the most positive way possible -- he's portraying a guy who is severely traumatised by the death of his parents and decides the best way to master his fear and channel his anger is to dress up as a bat and beat up criminals. He's not the most stable of individuals and there's a volatile mix of emotions there; this is what a novice Batman might be like. We also have to talk about the overall atmosphere informed by gorgeous visuals and production design (I absolutely love the look of the film, as well as the designs of the suit and car) that make the action scenes in particular pop. Gripping for its entire 3 hour run time, this is a very impressive first outing for Matt Reeves' ‘The Batman': it feels fresh and exciting, a murder-mystery that focuses on the crime-solving aspect and is punctuated by violent bursts of visually stunning action. I'm looking forward to seeing what he can do with the sequel.

I think that this movie brought a lot of good ideas to the table but ultimately fell short in a lot of ways. Oh also, spoilers ahead. 

 For a lot of the movie, it felt as thought they were building up to Bruce Wayne realizing the role he played in neglecting Gotham(not paying attention to where the renewal money is going, failing as a philanthropist) . But a lot of this is rather unexplored, as more emphasis is placed on the vigilante personality of Batman and how his mentality of vengeance has hurt Gotham more than helped it. I do think that this development of Batman is done well, but I really think the ending would have been much better if the film addressed how both Batman and Bruce Wayne failed Gotham, but now have a chance to be a symbol of hope for the city . With all this emphasis on how privileged Bruce Wayne is, it seems like a missed opportunity to not have the character realize how he can use his privilege to help those in need. Also, overall it just seems like Bruce Wayne is lacking from this film and I wish they had included more of Batman's development as Bruce in general.

I also think that one of the best traits of Batman is that, at his core, he is a kind person who cares about human life, which exists in contrast to his more stoic and violent persona. I would say the best example of this can be found in the Nolan films and in Batman:the Animated series. But a lot of that kindness seems to be missing from this film, and there are multiple times within the film where he just seems to disregard human life (the exploding trucks in the car chase scene, and even how he shatters the glass roof at the end leaving giant chunks to fall upon citizens.) It makes his no-kill rule, which is emphasized quite often in the film, seem hypocritical and just there for show.

A bigger complaint of the movie overall is that even though each of the actors did fantastic, it felt like a lot of characters were underdeveloped and their skills are never really explained. Like why is Selena Kyle so good at being a cat burglar? It seems like an oversight not to have this in her backstory. Also, the romance between Selena and Batman just seems to come out of nowhere and I wish more time was spent on developing that. The riddler seems to have all this information at his fingertips, and seems to have a good understanding of hacking but how he gets this information and how he acquired this skill is never explained either. Also his motive seems to switch in the last half of the movie, where he seems keen on exposing the rotten parts of Gotham, but then decides to kill a bunch of innocent people and targets the one uncorrupt politician in Gotham. It just does not seem like a logical progression of his character, and I wish they would have spent more time expanding on how this change occurs if they wanted to go this route. Also Jim Gordon is so underutilized in this film and the reason for all of his actions are boiled down to him being a "good cop" . Like why would this man risk his entire career for Batman? How did they even meet and why are they so close when Batman only been around for two years? For a lot of these questions about these characters, just a few lines of dialogue could suffice to explain it, which I guess is the frustrating bit of it. Especially because the run time for this movie is three hours, so not making time to include these bits of exposition seems like a bit of an oversight. 

Overall, I think that this film brings up a lot of interesting themes and takes on Batman but I really wish that some of them were explored more in depth. I think this film could have really benefited from cutting some characters so others could be more developed then trying to tackle all of these ideas and characters at once.

Convoluted, dull (including the lack of illumination... some of us can't see well in the dark, folks!), the subsidiary characters popping and out with little backstory or explanation and above all the man himself (oh, why does he have to speak in that sort of soft growl? Is it supposed to make us take him more seriously?). I found myself caring not at all for whatever shadowy traumas of the past made him head for the nearest bad fancy dress rental in the first place. Although this films lacklustre overall plot of the story, hiatus to the 'who done it?' or conclusion to this detective-esque zodiac like narrative could have been cleaned up, Matt Reeves commands a powerful cinematic masterpiece that's both visually stunning and compelling. The Batman's characters dialogue and reactions are meticulously written, proving Reeve's homework. Overall the film shines many lights in many directions, one of them being a core idea that is often not understood. 
This film is set in the early years of the The Bat, on a path to self discovery and the vigilante is still trying to figure out who exactly he is, and so is society. This is what The Batman does so well. The film centre's its story on the worlds best detective on a self discovery journey to prove himself. The films ultimate conclusion is a personal one, finally The Bat knows he has to be a Bruce Wayne once in a while, after being so absorbed in a character in order to escape the death of his parents. The length of the film doesn't undermine its sheer brilliance, with the whole cast including: Robert Pattinson, Zoë Kravitz, Paul Dano, Colin Farrell, Andy Serkis and John Turturro all out performing and exceed prior expectations.  
This film is not for all, however, it takes the meaning of 'superhero film' to another level, with comic-book movies retuning to a comic book narrative without desperately trying to appeal to audiences.

It occurred to me about three-quarters of the way through The Batman that I may be finished with this character.  There is simply nothing else that I need to be shown, largely because we have apparently stopped trying to make Batman movies entertaining and we have started running them through a pace that gets darker and darker and darker until the experience comes off as unsettling and a little sad.  Let's put it this way, this is the first comic book movie that brought back memories of Se7en.  We shouldn't be doing this.

The Batman will be a joy to those fans who want the bat to roll around in the muck, to fight for a Gotham that is in danger of being buried by it's own inhumanity and corruption.  They get that here in droves – nearly three hours of it to be exact – and I'll admit, the approach felt a little different.  In it's best moments, I got a sense of the movie that I wanted from The Dark Knight Rises, a movie in which the entire political structure of Gotham City was so in bed with the mafia that you are unable to tell the difference; and meanwhile a lone menace stands in the shadows who wants to punish the city for its legacy of sin.

The problem is that we've seen this all before.  Tim Burton did it,  Christopher Nolan did it.  By this point, it's just a difference in style.  Director Matt Reeves (Cloverfield, War of the Planet of the Apes) puts together a production that is breathtaking, but puts it in service of a movie that is not only bleak and ugly but way too long.  The movie has nothing to say that couldn't be wrapped up in under two hours.

Robert Pattenson's Batman is not exactly ground-breaking, though he does scale back a bit.  He's less talky, less emotional, more detached.  To effect, this gives the character a sense of presence and dread.  Unlike the Nolan Batman, this bat's philosophy for wanting to spend his evenings beating up criminals on the streets of Gotham kind of goes without saying.  He is also less dependent on gadgets.  They're here, but those wonderful toys take a backseat during the moments when he uses his fists to turn a thug's face into hamburger.

The setting and the story feels somewhere between old film noir and the aesthetics of Blade Runner.  Corner to corner, Gotham is a cesspool of crime and degradation while high above the 1% dance the night away in their penthouses (the movie is not subtle about this).  Keeping it that way is another matter.  The political arena of Gotham is, again, an interchangeable morass of mafia values and empty political promises.  Whose screwing who?  And what are the politicians doing with their evenings?  It's not surprising to anyone.  Nor is the element that brings Bats into the middle of all of this human waste.  Bodies are stacking up, clues are being left, and it is clear that Gotham has a serial killer in its midst.

What disappointed me greatly is that this isn't played as a mystery.  Batman works with Commissioner Gordon (Jeffrey Wright) to put the clues together to find a madman who calls himself The Riddller who, when he isn't leaving videos of his crimes, leaves cryptic messages teasing the police and eventually Batman himself.  What does Riddler want?  It's not all that surprising.  As I say it's not a mystery.  We know who the killer is and what he wants right from the beginning and so it's kind of a long, slow journey getting there.

What mystery resides in the film come from the characters, mainly Salina Kyle (Zoe Kravitz) whose reasons for wanting to infiltrate the viper's nest of the city's criminal empire yield possibly the film's only real surprise.  But, at least she has a function in the movie.  I never could figure out the role of Oswald Copplepot (Colin Farrell, buried under a heavy rubber fat suit) who works closely with the mob but seems to be part of this movie as a bit of character recognition.

I'll be honest, I didn't enjoy this movie.  There's a lot to admire but there is not a lot of entertainment in it.  It's sour and bleak and disturbing.  When Batman confronts the serial killer toward the end of the movie, it gave me the same queasy feeling that I had during the more disturbing scenes of Joker – that's not a good thing.  I guess that's the way of things in this post-COVID world.  Things have to be sick and disturbing rather than entertaining.  The Batman wallows in an atmosphere of rotting dread for so long that you find yourself begging for a little sunshine.  Please!  Somebody!  Anybody!  Tell a joke!  Throw a pie!  For Heaven sake, even Hamlet had a comedy relief!

You can tell The Riddler is a complete sadistic psychopath in this movie, someone to really fear. Definitely not inspired so much by Jim Carrey's version. I'm loving the aesthetic and look of this Batman movie. Reminds me a lot of the tone of Se7en. Definitely a darker looking movie then the other Batman's in terms of brightness. And I like that a lot. It sets it apart from the rest. I also really like how grounded in reality this Batman is. Interesting how people in this world don't see Batman as a hero or a protector. They see him more as a threat or a liability. 

This Batman is a lot more moodier, grungier, and even maybe a bit emo. That contact lens technology was pretty awesome. It records everything he sees. Awww, Andy Serkis is Alfred! That's so good. Waaaoooow! All the gothic architecture throughout Wayne Manor is gorgeous! Dude Colin Ferrel looks insane as the penguin! He's almost unrecognizable under all the prosthetics and fat suit. I don't care what anybody says about him, he's a great actor. That rat torture contraption around the guys head looked insane! I've never seen that before. That scene with Selena going into the lounge wearing the contact lens was masterful. 

That's hilarious how the same officer, Martinez, loves and admires Bruce Wayne at the funeral procession but despises Batman when he sees him at the crime scene. Jesus Christ, that car chase sequence was insanely good. Bat's car emerged out of that fire like a bat out of hell! That was amazing. I think I can say without a doubt that this has been the best Bat mobile to date. It's like a customized Mustang or muscle car. It looks so sick. I want it. I love Paul Dano's innocent little child-like smile. 

I think my favorite part about this movie is how it plays out like a Mystery/thriller and how grounded it is as a superhero movie. Beautifully cast and terrifically acted. The violin-tinged soundtrack really compliments the tone of the movie nicely. Dark spaces are used wonderfully throughout the movie, either serving as an entrance for Batman or a reminder for criminals that he could be lurking in the shadows. I love how the movie serves as a reminder of all the corruption and greed that lies within the powers of government, law and the wealthy. There's a surprisingly good amount of humor throughout the movie that comes out of nowhere very unexpectedly, and I love it. Overall, this Batman movie was an amazing and fresh addition to the line of other Batman movies that already exist. It's definitely one of my favorites up there with Nolan's trilogy and it definitely deserves a rewatch.

The only slightly positive part of "The Batman" is the portrayal of Catwoman by Zoe Kravitz.  Her costume is another story.  Whomever was in charge of wardrobe for this movie looks like the hit a thrift store for their inspiration.  Catwoman's mask/headgear looks like a ripped winter toboggan.  Even with the horrible costume, Kravitz is the one actor in the movie that actually makes me care slightly for her character and I want to root for her to come out on top. I the brutal first scene really set up a tension for me that made the dark, grimy Gotham in this film take on Batman really play with the imagination. Some of the other factors were unfortunately not as great. It was much too long and for all the wait, the ending was not the high point of the movie. While not an insufferably woke film, there was some woke hanging around in the back alleys of Gotham City that was hard to avoid for the caped crusader. 

*minor spoilers*  It was surprising to see how the character who had the most negative perception by other characters was not the anonymous and violent vigilante, but Bruce Wayne. None of those characters had ever met the young Wayne, of course. He was, despite being an orphan through a violent homicide, mostly a detestable rich kid billionaire. People either resented the soft-landing of being rich despite obvious, horrific trauma or they had other uses for him and he just wasn't serving their causes (politician Bella Real). It's hard to take it any other way except that Batman should expect to be always defending Bruce's white, privileged status and upbringing. The police on the other hand thought batman was a creep and a weirdo resulting in frequent altercations, insults and distrust. Also, the ultimate result of Batman's vigilante nights is not a safer Gotham, but the inspiration for violent internet chat room creeps who grab guns and start an insurrection (see where this is going?)

Thus, is the state of the Bat universe in 2022.  Patterson's Batman really doesn't have a lot to say in defense of his character, Bat or Wayne, so we'll have to see where future screenwriting leads. Hopefully in a far shorter sequel in 2024 where perhaps Bruce Wayne is more accepted as a wealthy, but inoffensive introvert who enjoys halloween all year long!

I feel like a LOT of how one will feel about this movie comes down to if you're watching it as a comic book fan, or if you're watching it purely as a stand-alone movie. As a stand-alone movie, it's fine. Not amazing, not bad.

The divide between the two perspectives comes down to The Riddler.

The portrayal of the primary antagonist of the movie is well done, and far more believable than any other I've seen. He isn't larger-than-life, he's got a more believable backstory, and his sense of anger and outrage fits in with an alarming amount of people out there today. His rantings, his reactions to Batman rebuffing him in Arkam, you can believe it all. He's a mentally ill psychopath.

The problem for me is that while he is a believable psychopath...he's not The Riddler. He doesn't fit the source material being adapted at all, and AS a comic book fan, that really bothered me. Additionally the pacing made the movie feel a bit dull, and Robert Patterson made an acceptable Batman, but a lousy Bruce Wayne.

Big points for Colin Farrell as The Pinguin, though. He was fantastic.

It's been a couple of days since I watched the movie on HBO Max. Before you berate me for not seeing it in the theater, my wife hates Marvel and DC movies, so there was zero chance I was going to the movie theater to see it. I knew it was coming out on HBO Max after it's theatrical release so I knew I'd see it soon enough. Not to brag, but I've got a X950H Sony Bravia TV which is incredible (85" 4K) and a new Sonos Arc, Sub and rear S1 speakers (an amazing system, way better than the Pioneer Home theater system I spent twice as much for). My point is I saw the movie as close to theater quality as I was going to get. BTW, my wife agreed to give the movie a chance and didn't move for almost 3 hours, she loved it.
Back to The Batman. I'm a huge fan of Christopher Nolan's reboot of the Batman franchise. Christian Bale was amazing.
This Batman is not Christopher Nolan's Batman. Hell his batmobile looks like someone shoved a GE jet engine into the trunk of a 69 GTO. He barely has any cool tools, but it doesn't matter.
This Bruce Wayne is angry and he is out for vengeance. He's driven by it. But he also has a soft side. When an important man is killed (I'm trying to avoid spoilers) you can immediately see the empathy he has for the dead man's son. 
This is a Batman on the edge of self destruction. He is without a true purpose. As the film unwinds, this state of mind is directly responsible for much of the decay of Gotham. 
Pattinson's brooding, angry Batman is spot on. He's only been Batman for 2 years and without the guidance of Alfred he definitely would have self destructed. All of this unfolds seamlessly and it is incredibly compelling.
Those that are critical are longing for the Nolan Batman. Slick, bad ass and up to his eyeballs in the best munitions and tech. That is not this Batman. We are witnessing the rebirth of a man. A man who just happens to be Bruce Wayne and Batman. 
The co-stars are perfection. Zoe Kravitz as Catwoman Is insanely beautiful and her character is one step above amoral. Jeffery Wright as Gordon is powerful and completely understated, he is probably the only true good guy in the movie. My only gripe was that Andy Serkis as Alfred isn't featured more prominently. I suspect that will change as the franchise moves forward. 
The real standout here is Paul Dano as the Riddler. I won't go into the relationship between he and Batman but needless to say this is not the standard good guy vs bad guy scenario. Dano's performance is creepy to perfection.
If you want to see cool gadgets and insane explosions, rewatch the Dark Knight series (I am not putting it down, it also went deep into Wayne's psyche). But if you want a compelling drama with some cool action thrown in, see this movie.

Went to sleep at the end credits, had breakfast watching it over again. It is a movie that suceeds mightily, helped along by our intimate knowledge of the legacy and mythos of The Batman. It honors the audience by dispensing with what we already know and delivering the "other stuff." The dark stuff that flambouyant costumes and Commedia del Archvillain usually distract us from. Pattinson's Batman is a shark for justice. Afraid that any touch from another human being, other than fist to face, might turn him back into a man who must feel. He can survive bullets, but never feelings. Pattinson conveys more than most actors in a sustained longshot, with nothing more than clenched jaw and the whites of his eyes. He may dispense justice like the sledge hammer we fantasize being, but he can't do what we do. Allow himeslf to love. The loyalty of Alfred angers him. An adoring public bothers him. A kiss. That kiss. It is the superhero's biggest struggle in this story. It disarms the monolith for one moment that exposes his longing for peace and his exhaustion from running away from pain. It is the moment that let me love him. Like all of us, he lets his work consume him and divert his attention. Away from the delusion that it's easier to fix a city than himself and the excruciating doubts about ever being able to find love or comfort among other people. Definitely MY Batman.

It was an interesting to see an attempt at a different sort of Batman, but ultimately it doesn't quite work. "Emo/goth Batboy" is not a very compelling character, even with that much eyeliner. To his credit, Robert Pattinson did about as well with the character as he possibly could have (and the movie will probably do surprisingly well with young girls). But ultimately Batman should be Bat-*man*. We want a ripped Christian Bale type who can take on multiple enemies in a somewhat believable way.

As you might expect, this movie follows the modern trend of filmmakers trying to "subvert" and effeminize (i.e. ruin) our traditional heroes. This Batman often looks like an awkward, stringy high school student with all the charisma of an awkward, stringy high school student. The film has to try to counterbalance this by going for an extremely dark, gritty, and solemn aesthetic/feel. Unfortunately this has the consequence of making the film a slog, and the runtime of nearly 3 hours doesn't help. 

This film is extremely monotone. The color scale of it is reminiscent of "The Long Night" episode of Game of Thrones. Somehow, it's always raining and cloudy in Gotham. Everything is dark, dark grey, in appearance and tone. Everyone always speaks in a slow, gritty, blandly "dramatic" voice. There is virtually *zero* light to contrast the copious shade in this movie. 

The film doesn't have much heart to it, or any meaningful levity. For contrast, go back and watch "the pit scene" of the Nolan film where Bale escapes the pit. The difference is astounding. Nolan made you feel something, and root for Batman. There's very little in this new film that makes us like, understand, or root for Batman. We aren't really shown what Batman's motivation is. I mean, you might argue "It's Batman, we already know what his motive is", but any movie should be able to stand on its own, so that motive should be spelled out and felt by the audience. In this movie, we go right into Batman doing his Batman thing, and we never really see why *this* version of Batman does what he does. The ultimate effect is that this version of Batman is not very believable. 

What are the merits of the movie? Well, nobody can complain that this movie is too cartoonish, or not serious enough. The Penguin is great. The plot is full of intrigue (although it's arguably a bit too complex and most viewers wont really follow it). The more grounded version of the Batmobile is cool. It is an admirable attempt at a different sort of Batman, but ultimately it leaves something to be desired.

The main villains of this movie?  That so many better versions came before it.
Decent performances from the main characters, but Gotham knocked it out of the park with villains, and this movie seemed to be ok with just good enough.

Besides that, weak action scenes and writing.  The Batman phones in the action with blurred backgrounds and verbal explanations of what's happening.  I shouldn't have to say this, but it is always more exciting to see a seawall get destroyed instead of just hearing about it.  And if Bruce really cares about Alfred, how is the first thing he says to him (after Alfred wakes from a coma) is, "You've lied to me all these years."  Lame.

And perhaps most importantly, how did they not learn from The Dark Knight Rises that you should be able to hear the dialogue?

I'm looking forward to the other upcoming DC movies, but not sure I'll even bother if there's a sequel to this one.

The Batman is an interesting take on a story told a thousand and one times. I am a huge fan of Batman and I am glad the film expects the audience to know the basic story. So they can skip straight to the story they want to tell with these beloved characters. The batman seen in this movie is one of his youngest iterations. Robert Patterson does a fantastic job, there are moments when you truly see him vulnerable and upset and Patterson does well. This version of the Batman was a lot more reckless and you can tell he is just growing into the role as the city's protector here. The cast was all A-listers and for the most part, it worked. The only one that stood out was Andy Serkis as Alfred, Andy is a little gritty for the role of the uptight and always perfect Alfred Pennyworth but his rendition of the character worked against Patterson's version of Bruce. Other than that I think the cast did very well. Zoë Kravitz stands out as Catwoman as she brings a lot of vulnerability to the role. Cat woman has always been seen as a sexy aloof love interest for batman. She certainly is that here but Zoë adds almost an innocent touch that brings the character to life. The role of the cat woman is also aged down to fit against this version of Bruce and it was nice to see their dynamic and how both of them were trying to grow into their vigilante personas. Jeffery Wright as Gordon was a brilliant casting choice, as soon as I originally saw the cast list come out I was thrilled to see his name and he did not disappoint. This version of Gordon isn't as straightlaced as others but I liked that and believed Wright played into that well. The movie was well cast and the visuals were stunning but the story was lacking in certain places. I found myself getting bored a lot of the time and I believe that is partly caused by the 2-hour and 56-minute run time. I did enjoy certain scenes where batman was investigating the crime scenes among actual police officers because we can see the dynamic between the law and "vengeance" as they would say in the movies. A lot of the time we would see him enter and leave a scene, so when he did do the famous disappearing act it was all the fun. This version of Batman was said to be a lot darker than a lot of the other versions and I can see that with the actor choices and a lot of the character choices themselves but it didn't land fully due to the film's need to still be pg-13. I believe the two things cannot be balanced. They referred to drugs as these eye drops and every time it was mentioned it completely took me out of the scene. It is not my favorite of the Batman films but it does place itself pretty high on the list. Would recommend it if you are a fan of Batman.

I went into Hollywood's latest attempt at portraying Gotham's masked hero with high hopes. I anticipated a moody film with darker themes and while I thoroughly enjoyed the hauntingly unsettling reimagining of the film's main antagonist, the vibe did grate on me eventually. R-Patts does well as Batman but doesn't create a believable Bruce Wayne. The slow pacing and overused "the police aren't comfortable with him being around" set-piece just didn't feel like it added much. 

The run-time felt long and while there were some genuinely great moments (and some beautiful cinematography), I left feeling frustrated.

I don't mind when films run long when they use the time to world-build or backfill character stories (e.g. the Snyder Cut of Justice League), but this oddly felt like a storyboard that could have been slashed to 2hrs and lost very little.

A decent attempt and I enjoyed the first real foray into grim territories with the character, but with so many good portrayals of The Batman on screen already, I do wonder why we keep trying to find a new angle.

Since its a remake of Batman you're going to watch it... but its just massively disappointing.  Really, its not worth watching and it just drags on.  I found myself checking my phone about an hour in confused as to how there was an hour and a half left - I thought it must almost be over.  The worst Batman movie I've seen in my life, but it had so much potential.  The writing, fighting, the protagonist, and overall story is what makes it so bad but the acting was also pretty weak besides a few good characters.

The cinematography is actually beautiful, I love the city building (even though Gotham shouldn't be NYC, it should be in NJ and its own city... but alas, these details can be debated), it had a semi-noir vibe to it which I actually think could've been darker but was cool... but overall, the acting was pretty weak.  The actual imagery was dark and hard to see almost, but by darker I mean it could've been more noir/the vibe could've been scarier.  It was close, though, on vibe.  Zoe Kravitz was good, but they just made some weird choices in the script with Catwoman and IMO the action/fights were terribly choreographed.  Them making Batman more of a detective was pretty cool, but I found the whole Riddler character to be weak at best, really not scary at all even though he was supposedly doing all these bad things and controlling the story behind the scenes.  Idk, just felt like a high school project for 2 and a half hours with Hollywood behind it.  Just didn't feel like Batman on top of that.  Wasn't a great story either and wasn't wrapped up, like they actually plan on making more of these?  They actually want that Riddler character to keep being the main protagonist?   

The most noticeable stuff were just bad choices in plot lines, easily noticeable plot holes many times in the movie, loose ends and side plots that don't make sense (um, what happened to Alfred and why did he just drop out from the movie), disconnects from the true Batman storylines, but worst was the inconsistencies of how Batman acted/fought/and the technologies he used.  As a billionaire detective-like Batman, you'd think he would use technology more... he had some super high tech contact lenses but instead of using a drone to search a building, he goes into some abandoned building with another guy and just walks around and gets into a bad situation.   I know he's supposed to be a genius, but him solving riddles immediately but then later getting basic parts of it wrong... idk just felt weird and stupid.  Alfred cracking some secondary code that didn't really make sense to get the word "DRIVE" which lead him to a random car... just none of it really tied together.  Lazy and bad writing should have no place in a big production or in something meant to be psychologically stimulating.... 

The Batmobile is just a semi-normal looking car from decades ago, with a jet engine on the back, that somehow can just plow through other cars, trucks, buildings, etc, and breaks the rules of physics.  Then there is the most cringey part in the glide suit... the way he fights to not kill and somehow has infinite grappling hooks that come from nowhere to hang guys from the ceiling instead of kill them while just walking through machine gun bullets that seem to magically bounce off his suit.  An explosion in his face doesn't even scratch his exposed skin somehow despite throwing him across the room.  At one point he jumps onto a falling part of a building and uses his batarang to cut a wire, and falls with the chunk of hanging metal and miraculously survives, rather than just being Batman and throwing the batarang at the cable... Batman starts to fight a room full of cops who didn't unmask him for some reason while he was passed out but is able to escape the precinct - almost no reason to even have this scene.  I mean, its like they never saw Batman fight before.  He is stealthy, he doesn't just walk up to guys and start fighting them, and they almost always had him walk up and walk through bullets like superman and almost never sneak attack people.

As far as Bruce Wayne goes, this depiction just makes no sense.  He doesn't fit the character at all.   This was part of the movie that just made it terrible as far as being a Batman fan goes but wasn't even majorly focused on... further, the Riddler knows and possibly reveals who he is which shouldn't happen.  Oh, and don't mention that he's physically way too small to be Batman and doesn't even look like Bruce Wayne has ever been depicted, in facial structure.  I just don't believe he is Bruce Wayne or Batman at any point in the movie.

I'd give this high school level writing, Hollywood level cinematography, just poor casting for Batman and some other characters, and overall the acting was bland and not great but not noticeably bad either.  The storyline was super weak and drawn out, this movie could've shaved an hour off and been better.  Would not really like to see any more of these made but will probably have to watch them because there won't be another Batman reprise for another decade.

If this isn't the summit of Batman filmmaking, it sure is near the peak. For what I want out of a Batman movie, The Batman hits nearly every mark. It is a dark and brooding story with all of the perfect Batman elements that have been sorely missed by previous entries - the mob, the internet, Batman the detective, and a broken Bruce Wayne struggling to find his place. My complaints are minor - I'm not a huge Paul Dano fan despite liking him in this role and a couple other small things - but none of them come even close to jeopardizing any aspect of how great this movie is. Pattinson is spectacular as both Bruce and the Batman and Zoe Kravitz is unreal as Selina Kyle - just a perfect casting. The story is fantastic and also leaves just enough room for some theory crafting of what will come next for Battinson.

For better or worse (usually for the better), The Batman is at his best when he's a detective first and a superhero second. A bleak, exciting noir with a ray of exhilarating hope. It doesn't really matter if we get a new Batman movie, especially if it goes down this exciting path. Pattinson and Kravitz were a match made in heaven.

I love Matt Reeves, he has proven to be a very capable director. But has definitely drop the ball with this franchise. For sure, not towards Joel Schumacher fluorescent, nipple variety. So I watched with an open mind, this reimagined, long awaited reawakening, and… found myself hating most of it. For the exception of Cat Woman, none of the characters were sympathetic, nor likable (including our mopey Batman), it seems, Gotham city has no good, happy people living in it, a regular depress, cesspool of evil and corruption, (counting Bruce Wayne's father???). The dialogue were long and ponderous. The scavenger, puzzle mystery scheme in itself, seemed overly simplistic and silly, more CSI meets Phantom Of The Opera than a Batman narrative, with lots of morose, mood inducing imagery taken right out of "Seven". The production designs and costumes were laughable (specially the Riddler's Son of Sam attire). The action scenes were average at best, and you never got that welcomed uplifting hero's moment, I stop caring, and watched with horror that I had two more hours to go… An excessively long, drab movie, in tandem with the snail pacing, made for sleepy time and torturous viewing.

After years of waiting, we finally have a Batman closer to what he really has to be, a hero who uses his brains more than strength, of course because he's at the beginning of his career he makes mistakes, which he also is. a great detail to show this more "Human" side. Watching the movie, I always noticed details from other movies like Seven and Zodiac, which are great movies to be inspired by. Matt Reaves' idea of ​​presenting a more "emo" Bruce Wayne was quite brave and worked perfectly, the other Batman movies failed to show this darker side of Bruce, perhaps because none of the other actors would have been able to. Robert Pattinson may not be (yet) the best actor to have played the character, but it's undeniable how amazing he is in the movie. The Riddler for me is the most debatable point, since as in Seven, we have here a villain who appears very little, unlike The Dark Knight, where the Joker appears a lot (to the point of seeming that the movie is his), but the little that he appears shows all the talent that Paul Dano has to make this type of character. But despite the focus being entirely on Batman, it didn't stop some supporting actors from appearing, this is mainly the case with Jim Gordon, who has a very important role in the film, being a true support for Batman. Zoë Kravitz Catwoman is amazing and passionate, her chemistry with Pattinson is really strong. There's also Colin Farrell as the Penguin, who leaves everyone wanting to see more. But what caught my attention the most was the way Batman was evolved, at the beginning of the film we see that he is more of a vigilant, someone who is just wanting to take out his anger, and at the end, he gets real and discovers that he cannot just be a vigilant or "Vengeance" he finds that there has to be more. Which makes me very curious about what this Batman will be like in the next movies.

Okay so the visuals were actually very good. The artwork is probably spectacular. Unfortunately the very blah movie almost made the good artwork hard to appreciate. At nearly 3 hours of run time, "meh" gets painful, especially considering how badly I wanted to like this, and how much I kept hoping it would get better. Anything moderately good was derivative. And most of the story just made me cringe. 

I do give full marks to the props, sets, and costume departments however. The batarang that doubles as the chest symbol was very cool. And the batmobile was pretty cool if far from stealthy. But even here nothing was really original, it was mostly good because it looked like all the great Batman stuff from before.

As a character, Batman was alright until the final scenes where he was almost totally ineffectual. But Bruce Wayne was almost non-existent, replaced by an emo version of an uncostumed Batman. No genuine pathos from any of the characters. There is nothing truly heroic or worthy of emulation from any of the characters. Our "greatest detective" and "only clean cop" behave like total noobs when they plug a thumb drive KNOWN to come from a "devious" villain into an unsecured police issue laptop. So our heroes are idiots. 

Of course so are our villains. The Riddler would be pathetic except that we don't even feel sorry enough for him to get that much. None of his riddles are actually challenging, and he doesn't even manage to be creepy because he's so dumb. The Penguin is nothing more than a common mobster, except that he's not even really good enough to make a good capo on the Sopranos. 

And Catwoman? She can't seem to decide what she is. I will say that Zoe Kravitz is stunningly beautiful. She fits with all of the other artwork. But the character falls flat, like all of the others in this movie. 

None of the characters suffer any kind of internal crisis or conflict. None of the characters grow or change. They all just bumble around reacting to one another in very predictable ways. 

Considering that this is a superhero movie, about one of the few men to be considered a superhero without "powers"... it was incredibly boring. Batman is supposed to be amazing, he ranks with Superman because of his intellect and character (and cool gadgets). But in this movie even the spectacle of a decent car chase was dry because it was "yep, guess it was time for one of those."

And no hate on Pattinson or anyone else for the failures in this movie, the faults lie exclusively with the script and direction.  

Almost everything awful about this movie comes from breaking a very simple rule of good writing: show, don't tell. Don't tell me that Jim Gordon is a good cop, show me him acting like one, the Nolan movies nailed that one. Don't tell me that a pretty young black woman will make a great mayor because she is pretty, young, and black. Show her acting with good sense and strong leadership (and not like a petulant child). Don't tell me that Batman cares about Gotham city. Show me what it costs him to try to make the city safer for kids to grow up in. Show me why that matters to him. Again, Nolan nailed that one.

In fact, just go rewatch the Dark Knight Trilogy, your time will be far better spent. Myself, I will try to pretend that this one doesn't exist in the cannon of Batman movies. Well, come to think of it, nothing significant actually happened, so that's easily accomplished.

Instead we have a grittier and more realistic Batman from that of the Nolan Trilogy.  Despite Bruce Wayne's amazing capabilities, he had to start from scratch some where.  We see a great noir detective movie rather than a superhero genre.  Robert Pattinson delivers a more tangible Bruce Wayne and realistic beginner Batman.  His acting shows a complete separation of the two characters.  His body language and fight style show a rough around the edges, taking several blows and by no means a master of his craft, yet.  Andy Serkis delivers a great Alfred, despite his limited lines and screen time.  Andy definitely has more to offer and future story arcs for this character.  Zoe Kravitz  also delivers, arguably, the best Catwoman/Selina Kyle. Yes, better than Michelle Phifer.  It was refreshing to show Batman's intelligence but key moments that he is still learning his thought process, strategy, and skills.  My only note that left me disappointed, was a scene where Batman is brought back to a police station after being knocked unconscious.  When Batman awakes, his cowl is still on his head.  I found this the only moment that let me feeling "yeah right?"

The Hook; an essential part of getting the reader's attention, as in this case, the viewer's attention, is magnificently achieved in this action film, and thusly pulled me in from Jump Street. I was willing to suspend my disbelief in the whole world of DC's Gotham, but alas, the tropes started pouring in. The use of just one guitar chord in the soundtrack as Batman walks toward the Penguin, trapped hanging upside down in his demolished car, hints at all the Robert Rodriguez grindhouse splatter ever made and had me shaking my head.


We follow the scars as they are covered by his shirt only to reveal the point of a cathedral common room in the Manor, The Martre's entrance. I would have settled for the kid staring back at me from the video of the previous night's patrol, to tell the story of what matters most to Bruce, but no, this is a hero story, hence the Sainthood dry-rub. By now, that's a foregone conclusion to this fan base, isn't it?!

The shift of dominance in roles has disheartened me greatly and enough to warrant considerable star erosion in this review. Jeremy Iron's portrayal of Alfred is more a tour de force in actually influencing his Bruce Wayne, which naturally would be the case, shedding new light on a facet of Alfred's story purpose - that is not enlightened nor awakened in any respect here. Andy Sirkis has his cajones roped in the opener, and it is a sign his hands are just there to be wringing over the pain he sees in master Bruce's eyes than actually building gear and pressing suits. To my utter dismay, Andy Sirkis' portrayal got nothing but worse after the initial scene, descending into a castration of character the likes of which I've never seen in a Batman movie. His limp reaching out for the hand of his master was flinchingly horrible. Alfred is an NPC, as we say in gamedom, in this movie and that accounts for most of the missing stars in the rating of this film.
It is an enthralling portrayal of Batman as he starts to find his footing in his second year as Gotham's lone vigilante. He is a brooding and dark figure, struggling with the rage he still feels, having witnessed his parent's brutal murder. He is stretching his muscle, finding his strengths, and exercising his demons. I give Pattinson's performance a 'B' for its convincing representation of Bruce Wayne as a somewhat young orphan grappling with relationships, his fears, and a woman's fierce and focused attention. The subject of which is also the cause of the erosion of star quality in this review. The elements within the love interest story were the most captivating and magnetic aspects of this plot. His treatment of this female character is demeaning though, as though a petulant heir apparent at The Manor were not getting his way with a disobedient nanny. I'm glad he didn't team up with her at the conclusion; the potential for her character is so much greater without him, even as a spin-off. The basic detective plot lost its interest with the way in which the names of the gangsters got me confused and it just wasn't as interesting as the slim beauty in the skin-tight suit, nor the Batmobile itself! I didn't know which Tony was the bad guy or the good, which eroded the rating even more. My understanding is that this director gets his three shots at the trilogy as well and my sincere hope is that more entanglements with female interests continue - it is the best of this rendition of our hero. It is a vision of Batman, that although dark and shadowy as the character himself, also offers us the light of relationship at the bottom of a very black crevasse, a crevasse we can not help but lean over the edge of to peer down into.
Colin Farrel's Penguin was a top-notch character acting job, as is expected from him always, and the casting of Paul Dano as Riddler worked as a very unstable villain. When I saw the actor's face I thought of the disturbed young man who menaced everyone in There Will Be Blood, provoking me to a verbal outburst of surprise. I have watched the film many times now and will again many more times as it is thoroughly enjoyable as an action film, with a few tired plot workings and worn-out rhetoric in the dialogue, the biggest crippler being the lack of dimension and depth in two very important characters; Catwoman and Alfred. And this Batmobile is one of the best, not a hell of a lot of bells and whistles just jet engines and beautiful wings for flight.
My anticipation of the next iteration of this Batman is high, but I'm wary, as DC's track record is worse than Marvel's in the arena of sequels. I'm always pulling for DC to take this genre to the next level of evocative cinema. Warner has been hit or miss thus far lately; hitting a great social empowerment ceiling with Wonder Woman, but not slamming it home with the follow-up which pandered to an age group and threw the rest of us under the bus. Here's hoping this Batman finds its stride over the next following set of movies with an improvement to the writing of secondary female characters, introducing more villains, love interests, and car chases. This film would be an advantageous point at which to unfurl the full breadth and width of the DC Extended Universe flag. Let's see which way the wind blows in the excursion ahead for this franchise.

Robert Pattinson as Batman? I went into the Alamo Drafthouse movie theater in Austin, Texas ready to hate this movie. As a sci-fi book author, and collector of comic books since the 80s, let's say I'm definitely a big fan of Batman. The first 20 minutes of the film was emo af and as aspected, Robert Pattinson doesn't embody the legacy of Batman - he isn't that muscular or built up (however any Batman movie is better than Zack Snyder catastrophe of a movie with Affleck walking like a Zombie in a malfunctioning Iron Man suit), and he is still Twilight sickly pale. All of this said to me, "no no no," this is NOT Batman. Yet, nearly half way into the film, it won me over. Here's why: the rich and emotionally complex narrative that informs on growth and social intelligence is a joy to watch. Seeing Pattinson riding a motorcycle with a backpack on - that doesn't feel like Batman. And it's not. This is something new. For diehard fans of the Batman character I would advise this: don't go into the theater or stream this expecting a superhero movie. This is NOT a superhero movie. This is an indie-film with IFC vibes all the way. What impressed me was the director, Matt Reeves, took the time to show Batman's vulnerable side, allowing to break the mold into a dynamic character as The Batman hurts, grows and learns from his pain and decides ultimately to become a better person than the one who solves every problem with violence at the end of a batarang. WARNING: this is not a Batman film. It is it's own creation. Not really adding to the canon of the Batman legacy as I don't get Batman vibes from this movie. Nor would I recommend it to anyone who is in the mood to see a superhero movie. Sure, it's dark and complex like other Batman movies but to the degree that Reeves completely changed who Batman is, that's not really Bruce Wayne anymore. The caped crusader here is willing to re-learn how to handle trauma an deal with his emotions in a very post 21st century way. The soundtrack really adds to the emo vibes and it's modern in a social way that none of the other Batman films are. I really enjoyed it. But, it is not a superhero movie.

To put it bluntly, if Batman were real, he'd be raising all the red flags that he's the kind of guy you want to run a mile from, from the totally creepy way he spies on Selina with binoculars while she's getting changed, to the careless way he just gruffly orders her to look at a certain man (while he's using her body to look through her eyes no less with special contact lenses) even though it places her in serious danger. Especially problematic is the tired, offensive trope that suggests Selina is in a relationship with another woman until, of course, she meets "The" Batman - strong, silent, mysterious - at which point any trace of same-sex orientation is abandoned and she's instantly converted to compliant, submissive heterosexuality. Maybe I'm reading too much into it, but I was left feeling as if Catwoman was just a naughty, immature little girl who constantly needs rescuing by "The" superior and sensible Batman, even though it's usually Batman's insensitivity and carelessness that gets Selina into trouble. Still, leaving aside the rather bad taste the sexual politics left in my mouth, it was otherwise a very gripping film with strong performances all round.

DC Comics and Warner Bros. Pictures's new Batman reboot is truly something else!! Directed by Matt Reeves, and starring Robert Pattinson in his incredible debut as the masked vigilante, it follows a deeply stoic Batman who is forced to investigate the city's hidden corruption and question his family's involvement when the Riddler, a sadistic serial killer, begins murdering key political figures in Gotham. This super-noir style of the movie is groundbreaking and works very well with the detective nature of the story, delivering one of the most mature and disturbing takes on the character. It is a gripping story full of suspense that keeps you at the edge of your seat, waiting for the mystery to be resolved during some enjoyable 3 hours. All the performances are excellent, the make-up department does an astounding job with Colin Farrell's Penguin and a few action scenes are especially top-notch. Also, shout-out to Michael Giacchino for the magnificent score.

Extremely shallow plot. The only crimes exposed by the important people the Riddler is murdering, is that they are "on the payroll" of the Informant. You don't get a clearer sense of what they did to merit death. They are just "bad" and for that, they are murdered. The Informant, also, only committed the crime of informing on Salvatore Marconi's drug bust. But isn't that a meritorious act? Why is that bad? Late in the movie you learn of another specific crime he committed that deeply affects Bruce Wayne, but the Riddler may or may not have known about that, so there is again no clear sense about why the Riddler needed to murder the Informant. Also, if the Riddler wanted justice, why did he murder the Informant when he was being arrested and led away to jail/prison? One would only do that if they wanted to prevent the Informant from divulging names/secrets. It makes no sense. The people and the Informant who were killed were just "bad" people. Don't think too much when watching this movie. You will get confused.
